INVESTMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"MARKET DEMOGRAPHICS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"LATIN AMERICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"ARGENTINA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"PAKISTAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"713","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395933830&p=2kx&v=1&x=nK-MoIJ5uhiuqssVEfvTPA","id":"29395933830","content":"By Ian Woodcock \n \nFor those not familiar with the term, \u2018Frontier Markets\u2019 refer to equity markets (usually in smaller nations) that are at earlier stages of political and economic development than larger, more mature emerging markets. \n \nTypically, frontier equity markets have modest market capitalisation and limited liquidity, but possess favourable demographics and have very good opportunities for long-term growth. \n \nOverlooked by many investors in recent years in spite of improved economic performance, frontier markets are still a segment of the equity model that is traditionally missing from most portfolios. \n \nHowever, many frontier funds are still trading at a discount to both emerging and developed markets, meaning now could be the perfect time to buy.  Below, I have provided a brief summary of the better-known frontier markets, and what 2017 could bring. \n \nArgentina \n \nRecent political changes have helped pave the way for an economic resurgence in Argentina, although even the president himself admits a complete recovery will take some time. \n \nA country with an abundance of natural resources and wealth but a history of wastefulness and miss-management, it seems the foundations may finally be in place for Argentina to re-emerge as a powerhouse in Latin America. \n \nEconomists expect inflation to be vastly reduced in 2017, and GDP to grow by as much as 3%.  After a long period of foreign investors climbing over each other to get money out of the country, we are now finally seeing capital moving in the other direction again, and the finance ministry has tallied over $32 billion in foreign corporate pledges. \n \nFrom an investment perspective, valuations are still relatively cheap, and now is the time shrewd investors will enter the market before domestic growth accelerates further and valuations rise. \n \nVietnam \n \nVietnam boasted domestic growth of almost 7% in 2016, making it among the fastest growing markets in the world.  In a relatively subdued global economy, perhaps domestic demand is king, and Vietnam is combining this with a huge influx of foreign investment to very good effect. \n \nA bold socio-economic plan for 2016-20 is targeting a continued 7% annual expansion, meaning it is set to out-perform most of its peers.  In addition, new regulatory and structural reforms are helping to add depth and liquidity to the markets, and 2017 looks to be another strong year. \n \nPakistan \n \nAlthough Pakistan continues to suffer from security and corruption problems, as well as from power outages, the IMF has indicated that the government has succeeded in pulling the country out of recent crisis and stabilising the economy. \n \nInterest rates are still way down, meaning positive news for risk-based assets, and 2017 could see the country upgraded to emerging market (EM) status.  I would expect to see some setbacks during the course of the year, but, overall, 2017 should still see exciting times and continued growth. \n \nFrontier Europe \n \nFrontier markets in Europe could see improved fortunes in 2017, although much of this depends on improving eurozone growth and the stability of relations with Russia. \n \nA positive Russian market could add liquidity and reduce volatility to a very reasonably priced and neglected market, but I would be wary of sudden and explosive changes sparked by geo-political events. \n \nGulf Cooperation Council (GCC) \n \nThe general consensus seems to be that all six GCC countries will experience a continued slowdown in 2017.  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Qatar should outperform their neighbours due to a lesser dependency on oil (UAE), and continued public-sector spending ahead of the FIFA 2022 World Cup in Qatar helping to drive domestic growth. \n \nAnalyst company BMI Research predicts average oil prices for 2017 to average around only $57 per barrel, and large budget deficits in Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Oman will ensure they lag behind, dragging overall GCC performance down. \n \nIf oil price projections turn out to be too conservative, the region could experience much better than expected performance.  Otherwise this is a frontier market to be cautious of, certainly for the next 12 months. \n \nIn summary, frontier markets could well hold the key to some of the best opportunities for growth in 2017, although, as always, you should carefully consider options before investing.  Low market valuations in key sectors indicate great potential entry points to the market, and there is no reason why frontier funds could not play a part in a well-structured portfolio, particularly with a longer-term investment view. \n \nThe writer is Investment Consultant at Chase Buchanan: ian.woodcock@chasebuchanan.com","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Emerging markets news","group":"Finance"},{"name":"Vietnam news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"United Arab Emirates Shane Bond on fire in a ten wicket win in Wellington; chasing down 336 at Eden Park; and Craig McMillan's century - the fastest by a kiwi - helping the Blackcaps seal a stunning whitewash in Hamilton. \n \nThe scenes at Seddon Park when Brendon McCullum hit the winning runs are unforgettable, and kiwis celebrated beating the old enemy like there was no tomorrow. \n  \nAll this against a team without Ricky Ponting, Adam Gilchrist, Andrew Symonds, Michael Clarke and Brett Lee.  \n \nBear that in mind over the coming week. Usman Khawaja's preparing for tests against India. David Warner - the top-ranked one-day batsmen in the world - needs a rest. \n \nAnd skipper Steve Smith's nursing a sore ankle. The Blackcaps will face a watered-down Australian side for the Chappell-Hadlee trophy, but it doesn't matter. Australia is Australia and, in any case, the Chappell-Hadlee series is all about us.   \n \nThe Aussies don't care. Their fans are apathetic. The crowds for the series across the ditch earlier this season were awful. So what?! \n \nThat's Cricket Australia's problem, not ours.  \n \nWhat is our problem is ensuring the Blackcaps remain competitive with the big brother, and with that in mind it's important they bounce back from the three-nil defeat across the ditch last year and win this series.  \n \nIf New Zealand Cricket - the players, the fans and the administrators - want the Chappell-Hadlee Series to have a future, then it's vital the Blackcaps perform on home soil against our fiercest rival. \n \nThe reason this series is on the calendar is because it guarantees three big gates for NZC, but it'll only continue to be a regular fixture if New Zealand can keep things competitive on the field. \n \nKiwis love their one-day cricket as much as they hate the Aussies, and in an age where bilateral cricket series often struggle for context and meaning, this is perhaps the only series that really matters to the fans. \n \nBut if New Zealand can't remain competitive against Australia, then the Chappell-Hadlee Trophy that fans and players covet will be left to gather dust in a cupboard in Melbourne as other nations and more lucrative series take priority for Cricket Australia.  \n \nThere's a point to prove for New Zealand in this series. There's a point to prove for the players who failed in Australia, for Ross Taylor whose runs were sorely missed across the Tasman, and for Kane Williamson who has a chance to outwit a rookie skipper in Matthew Wade and claim the big scalp his captaincy reign needs.  \n \nAussie allrounder Glenn Maxwell said earlier this week that New Zealand were a different side without Brendon McCullum, and that the team lack \"explosive, scary, unbelievable power at the top\". \n \nIt's clear that Australia no longer see the team as the threat they once were. We can save the PC vs console arguments on another article, since the new generation of game consoles released in the past year at now (almost) at par with high-end gaming PCs. \n \nFirst off, the Xbox One and the PlayStation 4 being to the current crop of eighth-generation consoles, but years after they were released we were treated to new upgrades in the likes of the PS4 Pro and the upcoming Project Scorpio. These consoles were not made to be replacements to the current generation, but cited as alternative options for gamers who want more powerful hardware. \n \nLet\u2019s talk numbers. The recently released PS4 Pro achieves 4.2 teraflops, enough for some games to be rendered in 4K or depending on how developers make it, improve graphic fidelity and visuals. \n \nProject Scorpio was announced to support up to 6 teraflops \u2013 meaning that it will top out all other consoles once it is released. To compared, Nvidia\u2019s latest GTX 1080 graphics card supports 10-11 teraflops. \n \nThat would mean games will look better than ever. Austin native. Austin High School/University of Texas alum. Has been in current position for three years and a professional librarian for 33 years.  Basic job responsibilities: \u201cI direct the operations of a state agency with a mission of ensuring that Texans have access to the information they need to be informed citizens. I do a lot of planning, project management, budgeting, and many meetings with staff, the public, and our board to make sure that all our projects stay on track and that we are developing in ways that help the state and our customers. I meet daily with the outstanding staff of our four major programs tasked with maintaining the archival historical record of the state.\u201d  Favorite/least favorite parts of the job: \u201cI most enjoy travelling the state and seeing the direct impact of our work, such as a student who learns a new technology skill in a library makerspace we funded with a grant, a historian who discovers some hidden treasure in our archival collections, or a person who reconnects with an ancestor via our genealogy collections. The least favorite part of the job is not having the resources to serve all the people who need our services.\u201d  Hobbies/spare time: \u201cMy wife and I love to travel, cook, hike and swim, and of course you expected this from a librarian \u2014 read!\u2019\u2019  Guilty pleasure: \u201cBinge watching Netflix on a Friday night and the occasional chicken fried steak are about as guilty as I get.\u201d   \n\u2014 David Henry","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Public payroll profile: Texas State Library and Archives Commission Director and Librarian Mark Smith","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Potter","zipCode":"79166","state":"Texas","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Amarillo","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Amarillo Globe News","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"192322601","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Amarillo Globe News","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://amarillo.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198463859","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:43:58Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:43:58Z","duplicateGroupId":"29394180355","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CRICKET","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"RANKINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"NEW ZEALAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"},{"name":"AUCKLAND, NEW ZEALAND; NEW ZEALAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA & NEW ZEALAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TOM LATHAM","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"362","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395934068&p=2kx&v=1&x=TwPCpU775nD7PGTjTu702A","id":"29395934068","content":"New Zealand won't field a specialist wicketkeeper in the Chappell-Hadlee Trophy opener, choosing opener Tom Latham to wear the gloves at Eden Park in his 50th ODI.      \n \nCaptain Kane Williamson confirmed rookie specialist 'keeper Tom Blundell, who has played one Twenty20 international, won't play the first of three fixtures against Australia on Monday.            \n \nIt will be the fourth ODI featuring Latham in the custodian role, having done so early in his career when batting in the middle order.    \n \nLatham's performance with the gloves in a domestic trial for Canterbury on Friday probably won him the nod over Blundell. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:00:12Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395934167","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"HOUSEHOLD APPLIANCE MFG","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LAYOFFS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TRADE TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"ECONOMIC NEWS; RECESSION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"MANUFACTURING FACILITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"AGRICULTURAL EQUIPMENT MFG","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"FREE TRADE TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"86"},{"name":"WAGES & SALARIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FACTORY WORKERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EMPLOYMENT RATES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DISMISSALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"INDUSTRIAL AUTOMATION","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"INTERNATIONAL TRADE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"64"},{"name":"MANUFACTURING OUTPUT","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ROBOTICS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"83"},{"name":"MAJOR APPLIANCE MFG","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"86"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; INDIANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"CHINA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; OHIO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; PENNSYLVANIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; MICHIGAN, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"MEXICO","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"NORTH AMERICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"723","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395934167&p=2kx&v=1&x=89I9G19Jg9CE8hUQLUnE5g","id":"29395934167","content":"The statistics are quite startling -- since 2000, the United States has lost 5 million manufacturing jobs. \n \nOhio, Michigan, Pennsylvania, Indiana and Wisconsin account for nearly a third of the manufacturing jobs lost, with wage levels in the manufacturing sector in these states either flat or sharply down. \n \nIt should not come as a surprise to anyone that President Donald Trump, who promised to bring jobs back to America, carried all five of these states. \n \nSo what accounts for this huge loss of jobs? Some of it was the result of U.S. companies shifting manufacturing operations to countries with lower wages. Maytag is an example of this. In 2004, Maytag shut down its refrigerator manufacturing plant down the road from us in Galesburg and shifted production to Reynosa, Mexico. \n \nThat, however, is only part of the story. Much of the job loss is the result of increased use of robotics and automation. When I first visited the John Deere Harvester Works plant in East Moline in the mid-1970s, highly-skilled welders were hard at work welding together various components of the combines the plant was manufacturing. Workers in protective gear were spray-painting parts for the combines, either John Deere green or yellow depending on what the blueprints called for. Today, much of the welding is done by robots while an automated system dips the parts to be painted in vats of John Deere green or yellow. In short, many welders and painters have been displaced by automation. \n \nThe broader picture tells much the same story. During the Obama years, U.S. manufacturing production increased by more than 20 percent. During the same period, however, manufacturing employment increased by only 5 percent, falling short of the number of manufacturing jobs lost during the 2008 recession. \n \nIn an online article entitled \u201cManufacturing Jobs Are Never Coming Back,\u201d Ben Casselman states, \u201cIn recent years, factories have been coming back, but the jobs haven\u2019t. Because of rising wages in China, the need for shorter supply chains and other factors, a small but growing group of companies are shifting production back to the U.S. But the factories they build here are heavily automated, employing a small fraction of the workers they would have a generation ago.\u201d \n \nPresident Trump has the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) in the crosshairs, blaming this 20-year-old treaty for the loss of U.S. manufacturing jobs. The extent to which this is the case is a matter of considerable debate. There is no question about a substantial number of U.S. manufacturing jobs being lost. But how much of this is the result of NAFTA and other trade agreements, compared to the impact of automation on employment levels? There is no consensus on this matter. \n \nA NAFTA provision states that a country can withdraw from the agreement six months after giving notice. If President Trump were to take unilateral action of that sort, the result would probably be quite chaotic. Most observers believe that he is not going to do that. Rather, his recent rhetoric suggests that his intent is to renegotiate the agreement with his counterparts in Mexico and Canada. \n \nThat, however, is where matters start getting quite complicated. In his inaugural address, President Trump made very clear his commitment to an \u201cAmerica first\u201d policy. Is there any reason to believe that his counterparts in Mexico and Canada would be willing to make concessions beneficial to the United States without getting something in return? And if not, what concessions would the United States need to make in a renegotiated trade agreement? Moreover, would the end result of a renegotiated agreement, when all is said and done, actually result in more manufacturing jobs in the United States, while diminishing the number of manufacturing jobs in Mexico? It is hard to imagine Mexico\u2019s president, Enrique Pena Nieto, agreeing to those types of concessions. \n \nThe situation is complicated by the fact that Mexicans are enraged by President Trump\u2019s unilateral decision to construct a new wall between the two countries -- a wall he said during the campaign that Mexico would finance because he would \u201ctell them\u201d to do so. President Pena Nieto has emphatically stated that Mexico will not pay for the wall. \n \nThere are a lot of balls up in the air. How this sorts out remains to be seen. \n  \nDaniel E. Lee is the Marian Taft Cannon Professor in the Humanities at Augustana College; danlee@augustana.edu .","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Dan lee"},"topics":[{"name":"Manufacturing industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Mexico news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Job markets news","group":"Business"}],"title":"Reason for loss of US manufacturing jobs complicated","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Rock Island","zipCode":"61265","state":"Illinois","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Moline","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Quad-Cities Online","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169681602","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"221"},"name":"Quad-Cities Online","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.qconline.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198465056","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:00:12Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:43:59Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Central Ave. in Phoenix.   \nThe planning area covers nearly 486,400 acres of south-central Arizona and lies within Maricopa and Pinal Counties. Population centers adjacent to the planning area include metropolitan Phoenix and the communities of Ajo, Goodyear, Buckeye, Gila Bend, Mobile and Maricopa, according to http://bit.ly/SDNMtargetshooting . \n \nThe purpose of the meetings is to present the draft management alternatives, answer public questions and receive public input to be considered as the planning process progresses. During the first 30 minutes of each meeting, the BLM will provide opening remarks describing the ground rules and will proceed to present the alternatives. The remaining time will be conducted in an open house format, during which staff will answer additional questions and receive input to be considered. Three meetings were previously held Jan. 19-21 in Phoenix and Casa Grande. \n \nThe 90-day comment period will close on March 15. All comments must be received prior to this date in order to be included in the final analysis. \n \nFollowing the public comment period, the BLM will consider all of the input and begin work to finalize the Draft Environmental Impact Statement and Draft Resource Management Plan Amendment. \n \nStakeholders and other members of the public are encouraged to submit their comments for the record through the BLM online land use planning tool, ePlanning. Written comments may be mailed to the BLM\u2019s project manager, Wayne Monger, at 21605 N. 7th Ave., Phoenix, AZ 85027, faxed to 623-580-5623, or e-mailed to BLM_AZ_SDNMtargetshooting@BLM.gov .","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Richard Dyer"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"BLM to host meetings on target shooting management on Sonoran Desert National Monument","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Maricopa","zipCode":"85373","state":"Arizona","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Sun City","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Apache Junction/Gold Canyon Independent","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"600076973","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2"},"name":"Apache Junction/Gold Canyon Independent","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://apachejunctionindependent.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://bit.ly/SDNMtargetshooting"],"sequenceId":"695198465850","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:24:55Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:44:00Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

And with our Trans-Tasman rivals back on top of the one-day world rankings, the Chappell-Hadlee Series promises to be a fascinating contest. Here are three key factors for each team. \n \nNew Zealand \n  Blackcaps players celebrate 2016 Chappell-Hadlee series win in New Zealand (Photosport)   \nThe Guptill factor: \n  Martin Guptill celebrates his century in Sydney in December (Photosport)   \nThe Blackcaps need a good start at the top of the order, so the form of Martin Guptill is massively important. He delivered 193 runs in the three-match series last time out against Australia in December, including an outstanding 114 in Sydney. \n \nA blistering 112 from 95 balls in the Ford Trophy this week showed that he's fully recovered from a hamstring injury and would have been manna from heaven for Blackcaps management. It's also worth noting that in the last two NZ v Aus series, five of the six matches have been won by the team batting first. So Kane, win us a toss or two! \n \nBoult from the blue: \n  Blackcaps bowler Trent Boult (Photosport)   \nRemember February 28, 2015? Well, it was a glorious Eden Park afternoon, as Trent Boult produced a spell of bowling that went down in World Cup history. At one stage his figures were 3-2-1-5, with the Aussie middle-order cast asunder. And while Boult has been somewhat inconsistent in recent months, he always raises his game for the green and golds. \n \nHis figures of 3-49 stood out in Melbourne last month, before New Zealand's capitulation and a 117-run defeat. But if Boult doesn't work his magic, then another Blackcap has to step up. You don't beat the best team in the world with run-of-the-mill performances\u2026 who is ready to write their own headlines? \n \nIgnore recent form: \n  Australia celebrates the wicket of Kane Williamson in December 2016 (Photosport)   \nThe last one-day series for the Blackcaps against Australia was a chastening experience. The closest they got to a victory was a 68-run defeat in the first match in Sydney, although at 185-5 chasing 324 we were never really in the hunt. \n \nBut everyone knows the Aussies are flat-track bullies who don't like the pressure! OK, the king of short-form cricket is no longer with us (Brendon McCullum, please come back), but with home advantage and the Kane & Ross show in full effect, the world champions could be in trouble.          \n \nAustralia \n  Australia celebrates Chappell-Hadlee win in December 2016 (Photosport)   \nHow do you replace David Warner? \n  David Warner acknowledges the MCG crowd after scoring a century against New Zealand (Photosport)   \nAustralia is obviously in confident mood, having given Usman Khawaja and the best batsman in the world right now, David Warner, time to prepare for the four-test series in India - so it's likely that Aaron Finch, Shaun Marsh or new boy Travis Head will be facing the new ball. \n \nFinch has only scored 43 runs in his last four ODI outings, while Marsh is another player under pressure, having been in and out of the side. As for Head, he impressed in the series against Pakistan, with 128 his most recent knock. New Zealand will be desperate to make early inroads, so how the opening pair respond could dictate the direction of the series. \n \nThe show must go on\u2026 and on! \n  Australian all-rounder Glenn Maxwell (Photosport)   \nAny player who calls himself 'The Big Show' obviously doesn't lack confidence\u2026 and while Glenn Maxwell is difficult to like, he's certainly a game-changer in the middle order. A very handy bowler, he's dug himself out of a recent batting trough to score two half-centuries in his last four one-day innings. \n \nAnd with captain Steve Smith also absent due to injury, the microscope will be sharply focused on whether Maxwell can deliver. However, the show hasn't been worth watching against New Zealand - and he's been Trent Boult's bunny. Three dismissals in five innings and a top score of 29 are not impressive numbers. But if he does perform, we'll be sure to hear about it.    \n \nNeed for speed: \n  Mitchell Starc in action (Photosport)   \nConsidered one of the most potent new-ball attacks on the planet, Mitchell Starc and Josh Hazlewood can intimidate any batting unit. While Boult is ranked the no 1 ODI bowler by the ICC, many believe Starc is more deserving (he hit top spot in March 2015). \n \nThe quintessential Aussie quick, he's mouthy, swings the ball and has an unplayable yorker. Hazelwood is another player not afraid to express his opinion. Check out this foul-mouthed response when a decision didn't go his way in Wellington last year. \n   \nBut with a 24.27 bowling average in the one-day format and an uncanny knack for bowling the ball outside off stump at great pace, the Aussie fans won't care. If these two bowl well, New Zealand could well struggle.    \n \nNewshuib.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: cricket news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Chappell-Hadlee series: Keys to victory","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","countryCode":"NZ","country":"New Zealand"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Newshub","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"602226314","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"36"},"name":"Newshub","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://feeds.feedburner.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198468504","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:43:59Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:43:59Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395934143","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"RESTAURANTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"997","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395934143&p=2kx&v=1&x=HST46cJo8sz572uTL2Triw","id":"29395934143","content":"W\n\nWhen it comes to pizza, I usually agree with the legendary Mel Brooks, who said, \u201cSex is like pizza, even when it\u2019s bad, it\u2019s good.\u201d\n\nThere are hardly any pizzas I wouldn\u2019t take a slice of if you offered me one. That is until I visited Rosati\u2019s in Jefferson Pointe.\n\nWhen I tell you the crispy, thin-crust pizza was the best pizza at this chain best known for its Chicago-style, deep-dish pies, that should tell you a lot. But I have a lot more to tell, including some examples of management ineptitude that had me flummoxed to think of a place with worse service. My thin-crust Godfather pie, which was topped with Italian sausage, fresh garlic, onions and hot giardiniera was quite tasty. The crust crunched like a cracker, the pickled mix of vegetables gave it a punch of flavor and there was plenty of sausage. If you love giardiniera, you will love this pie.\n\nI had half of it without the spicy pickled stuff, and liked it even more as the roasted garlic was more pronounced. I would order this pizza this way every time because it gave me the best of both worlds.\n\nMy thin White Pizza was also good, but it was not supposed to be thin. I asked for it with the double-dough crust \u2013 a slightly thicker crust with a hand-rolled edge. My server admitted her mistake and offered to cut me a break on the bill, but the pizza was so good that I declined.\n\nThis pizza had olive oil instead of red sauce, fresh garlic, sautéed spinach and fresh tomato slices. It was exactly what I expected and though this thin crust was not as crunchy as the Godfather, it was still acceptable.\n\nThe Chicago-style was not acceptable in any way. And I would turn it down if you offered me a slice.\n\nIt had a dreadfully soggy bottom crust \u2013 so soggy the thick layer of cheese actually had more texture. The chunky pomodoro sauce on top was also horribly salty, which added to its awfulness.\n\nThe pizza was served on a dimpled silicone tray that was full of greasy and watery runoff from the poorly reduced sauce, which is probably why that crust was so soggy.\n\nRosati\u2019s does not cook its deep-dish in a deep dish or pan at all, I was told by my server. She said the restaurant uses conveyor ovens instead of high-heat deck ovens. Had I known that before I ordered, I doubt I would have even dared try a Chicago pie there in the first place.\n\nIt is also worth noting that I was warned that I would have to wait about 40 minutes for a Chicago pizza, and it, indeed, took that long. However, I was not warned of a wait when I ordered the thin pies and they, too, took 40 minutes to arrive. \u2022 Dough Nuggets \u2013 I received a huge order of these nicely browned, tender, Parmesan- and herb-dusted beauties that were sitting in a pool of butter. Easily the best appetizer.\n\n\u2022 Chicken wings \u2013 They were pretty big, and the Parmesan-garlic seemed a bit crispier than the standard Buffalo.\n\n\u2022 Turtle Cookie Dough Fudge Brownie \u2013 This dessert had a dense thin brownie topped with a layer of chocolate chip cookie dough with layers of caramel and chopped pecans on top. I would have it again.\n\n\u2022 Side salad \u2013 Dreadfully plain with an iceberg-heavy mix of iceberg and romaine lettuce and few onions and grape tomatoes and shaved Parmesan.\n\n\u2022 Penne and Grilled Chicken a la Vodka \u2013 It had a creamy sauce I liked with a fair amount of tender chicken, but no better than what I could get at a quick-service Italian restaurant for much less money.\n\n\u2022 The Cheef sandwich \u2013 It had a generous amount of tender, juicy, thin-sliced Italian beef, but that beef had no seasoning or flavor. I had it with sweet peppers and giardiniera, and they were the only thing I could taste. The au jus was also flavorless.\n\nThere also was no real atmosphere to speak of at Rosati\u2019s. It is nice inside, but has no character. It has standard wooden walls, a big stainless steel bar, black exposed ceiling and matching tile floor that screams turnkey business, which is what this spot in Jefferson Pointe has become over the years. During one visit, when there were only a few parties in the place and a number of empty tables, I was asked to wait 15 minutes or so while a table was cleared. That special table they cleared for me was next to the kitchen door with all of the noise coming from it. I then asked to be moved and was obliged \u2026 right to one of the tables that was empty as soon as I walked in the door.\n\nDuring another visit on a busy weekend when the place was packed, there was a large booth and a four-top table open when I submitted my name. I was then told I would have to wait about 35 minutes to be seated. I pointed to the empty tables and asked why I could not be seated there. I was told the servers were overwhelmed and could not handle waiting on me.\n\nI requested a manager and asked if my party could at least be seated with the understanding we would face a wait. Again, I was refused. He would rather we stand.\n\nDuring each visit, Rosati\u2019s seemed overwhelmed and the service suffered. My servers made sure to tell me as soon as they came to my table how understaffed they were and how bad a day they were having.\n\nI guess they hadn\u2019t been given a chance to sit down either. Gallery hours are Tuesdays to Fridays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Entry to the gallery is always free. \n \nRichardson started painting about four years ago. He started experimenting with leftover art supplies from one of his wife\u2019s hobbies. Amazed at what artists could do with paint and paper, he decided to try. He continued until he was pleased with the results. \n \nBeing an enthusiastic lover of nature, it was only natural for him to prefer painting landscapes. His medium of choice is acrylic. He has great admiration for the work of other artists but is determined to continue his course in his style with no training. \n \nColor and design workshop: Margaret Chouest will teach the workshop Monday at the gallery. TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1661","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395934235&p=2kx&v=1&x=NSYGBZykwsEgiD4tNru1CQ","id":"29395934235","content":"(CNN) -- The Department of Homeland Security said on Sunday it will comply with federal orders not to deport detained travelers. \n  \n  \nThis comes after a federal judge in New York granted an emergency stay Saturday night for citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries who have already arrived in the US and those who are in transit, and who hold valid visas, ruling they cannot be removed from the US. \n \nThat move limited part of President Donald Trump's executive order barring citizens from those countries from entering the US for the next 90 days. \n \nSimilar legal rulings were made in Virginia and Washington state after the New York ruling was made. \n \n\"The Department of Homeland Security will comply with judicial orders; faithfully enforce our immigration laws, and implement the president's Executive Orders to ensure that those entering the United States do not pose a threat to our country or the American people,\" the department said. \n \nOn Saturday evening, the ACLU argued in a federal court in New York for a nationwide stay that would block the deportation of all people stranded in US airports under what the group called \"President Trump's new Muslim ban.\" \n \nUS District Judge Ann Donnelly granted the stay. \n \n\"The petitioners have a strong likelihood of success in establishing that the removal of the petitioner and other similarly situated violates their due process and equal protection guaranteed by the United States Constitution,\" Donnelly wrote in her decision. \n \n\"There is imminent danger that, absent the stay of removal, there will be substantial and irreparable injury to refugees, visa-holders, and other individuals from nations subject to the January 27, 2017, Executive Order.\" \n \nThe civil rights group is representing dozens of travelers held at John F. Kennedy International Airport Friday and Saturday, including two Iraqis with ties to the US military who had been granted visas to enter the United States. \n \nThe ruling does not necessarily mean the people being held at airports across the US are going to be released, said Zachary Manfredi, from Yale's Worker and Immigrant Rights Advocacy Clinic, who helped draft the emergency stay motion. \n \n\"The judge's order is that they (lawful visa/green card holders) not be removed from the US -- it doesn't immediately order that they be released from detention,\" he told CNN. \n \n\"We are hoping that CBP (Customs and Border Patrol), now that they no longer have a reason to detain them, will release them. But it is also possible they could be transferred to (other) detention facilities.\" \n \n\"We are getting the order to as many CBP officers as possible right now,\" he added. \n \nThe United States denied entry to 109 travelers heading to the country at the time the ruling was signed, a Department of Homeland Security official said. The agency would not say how many of them were sent already home and how many were detained. \n \nACLU Executive Director Anthony D. Romero praised the ruling, saying \"our courts today worked as they should as bulwarks against government abuse or unconstitutional policies and orders. On week one, Donald Trump suffered his first loss in court.\" \n \nLee Gelernt, deputy director of the ACLU's Immigrants' Rights Project, who argued the case, said the ruling \"preserves the status quo and ensures that people who have been granted permission to be in this country are not illegally removed off U.S. soil.\" \n \nLawsuit is first challenge to executive order \n \nThe class-action lawsuit is the first legal challenge to Trump's controversial executive order, which indefinitely suspends admissions for Syrian refugees and limits the flow of other refugees into the United States by instituting what the President has called \"extreme vetting\" of immigrants. \n \nThe two Iraqis, Hameed Khalid Darweesh and Haider Sameer Abdulkaleq Alshawi, had been released by Saturday night. But lawyers for other detained travelers said in a court filing that \"dozens and dozens\" of individuals remained held at JFK. \n \nSimilar legal actions had been initiated in other states.. \n \nA federal court in Washington state issued a stay forbidding travelers being detained there from being sent back to their home country. \n \nA federal court in Virginia has issued a temporary restraining order saying several dozen permanent residents returning from trips abroad should have access to lawyers while they are being detained at Dulles International Airport and these residents cannot be removed from the United States for seven days. \n \nTrump's order, signed Friday, bars travel from seven Muslim-majority countries, including Iraq, to the US for 90 days. It also suspends the US Refugee Admissions Program for 120 days until it is reinstated \"only for nationals of countries for whom\" members of Trump's Cabinet deem can be properly vetted. \n \nReleased under special circumstances \n \nAccording to court papers, both Darweesh and Alshawi were legally allowed to come into the US but were detained in accordance with Trump's order. \n \nDarweesh, who worked as an interpreter for the US during the Iraq War, was released from detention early Saturday afternoon. \n \n\"America is the land of freedom,\" he told reporters at the airport shortly after his release. \"America is the greatest nation.\" \n \nA source with knowledge of the case confirmed Darweesh will be allowed into the US due to provisions in Trump's order that allow the State and Homeland Security departments to admit individuals into the US on a case-by-case base for certain reasons, including when the person is already in transit and it would cause undue hardship and would not pose a threat to the security of the US. \n \nThe suit said Darweesh held a special immigrant visa, which he was granted the day of Trump's inauguration on January 20, due to his work for the US government from 2003 to 2013. \n \nAlshawi was released Saturday night, according to his attorney, Mark Doss. \n \nRep. Nydia Velazquez, D-New York, who had arrived at JFK by early Saturday afternoon to try and secure the release of the two Iraqis, railed against Trump's order and pledged continued action. \n \n\"This should not happen in America,\" Velazquez said following Darweesh's release. \"One by one, street by street, if we have to go to court, we will fight this anyplace, anywhere.\" \n \n'The executive order is unlawful' \n \nThe lawsuit said the US granted Alshawi a visa earlier this month to meet with his wife and son, whom the US already granted refugee status for her association with the US military. \n \nThe lawyers for the two men called for a hearing because they maintain the detention of people with valid visas is illegal. \n \n\"Because the executive order is unlawful as applied to petitioners, their continued detention based solely on the executive order violates their Fifth Amendment procedural and substantive due process rights,\" the lawyers argue in court papers. \n \nCourt papers said Customs and Border Protection authorities did not allow the lawyers to meet with the men and told them to try reaching Trump. Velázquez and fellow New York Democratic Rep. Jerrold Nadler said they attempted to speak to Darweesh and Alshawi at JFK's Terminal 4 earlier Saturday but were denied. \n \n\"When Mr. Darweesh's attorneys approached CBP requesting to speak with Mr. Darweesh, CBP indicated that they were not the ones to talk to about seeing their client. When the attorneys asked, 'Who is the person to talk to?' the CBP agents responded, 'Mr. President. Call Mr. Trump,'\" the court papers read. \n \nDoss, an attorney with the International Refugee Assistance Project, told CNN his clients knew they had to get to the US as soon as possible so they boarded the first flight they could. \n \nThe two men had been allowed to make phone calls. They do not know each other, and it is unclear if they were held together or separately, or if they were kept in a holding cell, according to Doss. \n \n\"Our courageous plaintiff and countless others risked their lives helping US service members in Iraq. Trump's order puts those who have helped us in harm's way by denying them the safe harbor they have been promised in the United States,\" said Karen Tumlin, the legal director of the NILC. \n \nThe lawsuit was earlier reported by The New York Times. \n \nLegality questioned \n \nTrump's executive order, titled \"Protection Of The Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into The United States,\" makes good on his longtime campaign promise to tighten borders and halt certain refugees from entering the United States. \n \nThe countries impacted are Iran, Iraq, Syria, Sudan, Libya, Yemen and Somalia, according to a White House official. It also caps the total number of refugees admitted into the United States during the 2017 fiscal year at 50,000, down more than half from the current level of 110,000. \n \n\"I am establishing new vetting measures to keep radical Islamic terrorists out of the United States of America,\" Trump said during the signing at the Pentagon. \"We don't want them here.\" \n \nAn administration official told CNN if a person has a valid visa to enter the US but is a citizen of one of the seven countries under the temporary travel ban, then the person cannot come into the US. If the person landed after the order was signed Friday afternoon, then the person would be detained and put back on a flight to their country of citizenship. \n \nDepartment of Homeland Security officials acknowledged people who were in the air would be detained upon arrival and put back on a plane to their home country. An official was not able to provide numbers of how many have already been detained. \n \nAfter the federal orders were issued, the department said it \"will continue to enforce all of the president's Executive Orders in a manner that ensures the safety and security of the American people. \n \n\"The president's Executive Orders remain in place-prohibited travel will remain prohibited, and the U.S. government retains its right to revoke visas at any time if required for national security or public safety. \n \n\"The president's Executive Order affects a minor portion of international travelers, and is a first step towards reestablishing control over America's borders and national security.\" \n \nCNN's Kevin Bohn, Ellie Kaufman, Patricia Pedraza, Sheena Jones, Mohammed Tawfeeq, Rachel Crane, Chris Welch and Sarah Jorgensen contributed to this report.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US security news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Iraq news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Breaking News: Homeland Security to comply with orders not to deport travelers 19 MIN","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Polk","zipCode":"50309","state":"Iowa","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Des Moines","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"KCCI","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169659157","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1116"},"name":"KCCI","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","National","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.kcci.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198469481","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:44:00Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:19:09Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395844002","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"GRANDCHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"SPONSORSHIP","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"PARKING SPACES & FACILITIES","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"FUNDRAISING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"RUNNING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"87"},{"name":"COOKING & ENTERTAINING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; LOUISIANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"}],"wordCount":"607","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395934236&p=2kx&v=1&x=QGMUFQL0qb3Rwb3PYPk7hQ","id":"29395934236","content":"By Dan Boudreaux Staff Writer  \nCooler weather returned to Houma just in time as the United Way for South Louisiana kicked off its annual SOUPer Bowl charity cook-off Saturday. \n \nWith rows of tents set up in the parking lot of the Courtyard by Marriott in Houma, local businesses and groups whipped up their best soups, bisques, chilis and gumbos to raise money for the United Way for South Louisiana and to vie to for the coveted first place trophy. The event charged $5 for a wristband that allowed attendees to go to the various booths and a coin that allowed people to vote for their favorite dish. \n \n\"The turnout's been fabulous,\" said Ashlee Champagne with the United Way for South Louisiana. \"We have new sponsors this year, but it's great that the public has really come out today.\" \n \nOver 100 people were milling about the Marriott parking lot, trying out the various samples from the 24 teams that were vying to be this year's supreme soup chef. Along with different soups, drinks and baked goods were for sale, charity raffles were being held, and the band, Pot 2 LA, played an eclectic mix of energetic and fun music. \n \nAt only one hour into the event, some of the competitors had completely run out of samples. Ampol Services had made 10 gallons of its smoked brisket chili and still ran out so fast that the cooks said they didn't even get a chance to eat any of it. \n \n\"We only got to try it when we were cooking it,\" said Barry Champagne. \n \nSome interesting twists on the definition of soup were handed out at the event, too. Along with red bean gumbo and apple pie soup, the soup that won the \"Fan Favorite\" award was Synergy Bank's \"souptini.\" It was a loaded baked potato soup served in a disposable martini glass with a Parmesan crusted pig in a blanket on a toothpick instead of the traditional olive. The team also provided free tropical virgin martinis in an area of tables it set up next to its booth. \n \n\"The marketing department came up with it,\" said Missy Hutchinson with Synergy Bank. \"They're really creative.\" \n \nChristine Martin, who attended with her granddaughter, Brelynn, said she had been coming to the event since the very first SOUPer Bowl and said the crowd was \"fantastic.\" \n \n\"It's at least tripled in size since the first one and it's fabulous,\" Martin said. \"You feel like you're at a fair with all these people.\" \n \nA first for the event was the 5K run that started before the SOUPer Bowl at 9:30 a.m. The race had 50 runners participating and the trophies, which depicted little running chefs in honor of the cook-off, were provided by Grand Isle Shipyard Inc. The winner of the race was Matt Kelso, who said it was more than just a race. \n \n\"It's a great little event for a great cause. It's not about winning a race, it's about helping the community,\" Kelso said. \n \nAs the event began winding down, the coins were counted and the winners were announced. \n \nIn third place was Sonoco with its smoked turkey and green onion sausage gumbo. In second place was Terrebonne General Medical Center with its seafood bisque. And in first place was GSES/Workforce Logistics with its crawfish and smoked corn soup. The team, named Team \"No-Tell,\" was made up of head chef Joey Rogers, Randy Steib, Maria Chaisson and Eddie Doiron. \n \n\"This is our first year participating and only our second year here and it feels great,\" said Steib after his team won. \"We made soup great again.\" \n \nAll proceeds for the event went to the United Way for South Louisiana.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: latest","group":"Entertainment"}],"title":"SOUPer Bowl warms up patrons on a chilly day","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Lafourche","zipCode":"70301","state":"Louisiana","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Thibodaux","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daily Comet","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169668587","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"132"},"name":"Daily Comet","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Consumer","Arts"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.dailycomet.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198469650","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:19:09Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:44:00Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:07:30Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395844004","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"COASTAL AREAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LIBRARIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"60"},{"name":"ANTHROPOLOGY & ARCHAEOLOGY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"ARCHAEOLOGY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"EROSION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CUSTOMS & CULTURAL HERITAGE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"INDIGENOUS PEOPLES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"WRITERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"NATIVE AMERICANS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"HISTORIC SITES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"FAMILY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"HISTORIC DISTRICTS & STRUCTURES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"MISSISSIPPI RIVER","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; LOUISIANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"623","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395934237&p=2kx&v=1&x=59DA5Pk8pDwKj1EOb8HOMg","id":"29395934237","content":"By Dan Boudreaux Staff Writer  \nAlthough most assessments of what could be lost to coastal erosion have focused on modern buildings, one often overlooked piece of Louisiana\u2019s culture that could be lost is the historical legacy of the state\u2019s Native American tribes. \n \nThis has been a major topic on the mind of Jayur Mehta. Mehta received his Ph.D. in anthropology with a focus in archaeology from Tulane and has been studying the millennia-old mounds along the Gulf for many years. He said he believes the ancient monuments are at risk. \n \n\u201cLouisiana\u2019s coastal heritage is incredibly threatened from coastal erosion, sea-level rise and human interference,\u201d Mehta said. \u201cIt\u2019s all at risk.\u201d \n \nMehta is studying the mounds along the Louisiana coast with Tulane doctoral candidate Elizabeth Chamberlain and says the mounds are a rarity when considered next to other similar ancient monuments. \n \n\u201cWe have no evidence of the people of coastal Louisiana engaging in any kind of agriculture,\u201d Mehta said. \u201cMore broadly across the world, monument building is tightly tied to agriculture. Only in a few locations like here and coastal Peru do you see monuments without agriculture.\u201d \n \nMehta said these mounds are culturally and historically significant, pointing to the fact that the mound at Poverty Point in north Louisiana is a Unesco World Heritage Site alongside the Great Pyramids of Giza and the Taj Mahal as proof of their importance. \n \nAnd studying these mounds and the movement of the ancient tribes, he has gotten some insight into why the people of Louisiana would abandon one settlement and move to another. \n \n\u201cThere are older settlements to the west and younger settlements to the east,\u201d Mehta said. \u201cWe don\u2019t really understand the mechanism of abandonment and resettlement, but, broadly speaking, the settlements seemed to align with the age of the Delta.\u201d \n \nAccording to Mehta, from 400-1400 A.D., the outflow of the Mississippi River was Bayou Lafourche and it was around this time that the mounds in the region were built. One of the more impressive mounds that Mehta mentioned was the one at Bayou Grand Caillou that is about 26.25 feet high. \n \nThere are also mounds in the Dulac area. Although one that was located near Bayou Hardware has been destroyed, two still exist off Shrimpers Row. \n \n\u201cI think it\u2019s really amazing and beautiful from the top of it,\u201d said Candace Chauvin, a member of the United Houma Nation whose family lives next door to the mound. \u201cIt\u2019s surprising that so many people don\u2019t even know about their history. It\u2019s so important.\u201d \n \nChauvin, who was in attendance for Mehta\u2019s recent presentation on the subject at the Grand Caillou Library, said she wishes more could be done to save them. \n \n\u201cThey\u2019re just disappearing. I really wish there was some way to preserve them,\u201d Chauvin said. \u201cI\u2019m so glad Dr. Mehta did his presentation at the library. People need to know about this stuff.\u201d \n \nMehta is also a humanities teacher at the New Orleans Center for the Creative Arts and a principal at the Gulf Communities Research Institute, a nonprofit dedicated to \u201cpreserving the health, resilience, and lifeways of coastal peoples.\u201d \n \nAccording to Mehta, the current land loss projections are threatening to wash away the mounds outside of levee rings. \n \nHe also says even though places like Dulac and Bayou Grand Caillou are \u201cprotected for some time,\u201d if we don\u2019t fight land loss and reintroduce sedimentation and subsistence, it\u2019s \u201cabsolutely possible we will lose these sites.\u201d \n \n\u201cWe have to do more. We know that historically the Mississippi River would create around half-a-football field of land an hour, yet we\u2019re losing an entire football field an hour now,\u201d Mehta said, quoting recent land loss studies. \u201cIt\u2019s scary that natural systems aren\u2019t able to keep up anymore. We need to do more.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: latest","group":"Entertainment"}],"title":"Native American mounds threatened by land loss","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Lafourche","zipCode":"70301","state":"Louisiana","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Thibodaux","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daily Comet","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169668587","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"132"},"name":"Daily Comet","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Consumer","Arts"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.dailycomet.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198469817","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:07:30Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:44:00Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"IRAQ","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1661","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395934262&p=2kx&v=1&x=L5IH82DejDW11eWGB92mwQ","id":"29395934262","content":"(CNN) -- The Department of Homeland Security said on Sunday it will comply with federal orders not to deport detained travelers. \n  \n  \nThis comes after a federal judge in New York granted an emergency stay Saturday night for citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries who have already arrived in the US and those who are in transit, and who hold valid visas, ruling they cannot be removed from the US. \n \nThat move limited part of President Donald Trump's executive order barring citizens from those countries from entering the US for the next 90 days. \n \nSimilar legal rulings were made in Virginia and Washington state after the New York ruling was made. \n \n\"The Department of Homeland Security will comply with judicial orders; faithfully enforce our immigration laws, and implement the president's Executive Orders to ensure that those entering the United States do not pose a threat to our country or the American people,\" the department said. \n \nOn Saturday evening, the ACLU argued in a federal court in New York for a nationwide stay that would block the deportation of all people stranded in US airports under what the group called \"President Trump's new Muslim ban.\" \n \nUS District Judge Ann Donnelly granted the stay. \n \n\"The petitioners have a strong likelihood of success in establishing that the removal of the petitioner and other similarly situated violates their due process and equal protection guaranteed by the United States Constitution,\" Donnelly wrote in her decision. \n \n\"There is imminent danger that, absent the stay of removal, there will be substantial and irreparable injury to refugees, visa-holders, and other individuals from nations subject to the January 27, 2017, Executive Order.\" \n \nThe civil rights group is representing dozens of travelers held at John F. Kennedy International Airport Friday and Saturday, including two Iraqis with ties to the US military who had been granted visas to enter the United States. \n \nThe ruling does not necessarily mean the people being held at airports across the US are going to be released, said Zachary Manfredi, from Yale's Worker and Immigrant Rights Advocacy Clinic, who helped draft the emergency stay motion. \n \n\"The judge's order is that they (lawful visa/green card holders) not be removed from the US -- it doesn't immediately order that they be released from detention,\" he told CNN. \n \n\"We are hoping that CBP (Customs and Border Patrol), now that they no longer have a reason to detain them, will release them. But it is also possible they could be transferred to (other) detention facilities.\" \n \n\"We are getting the order to as many CBP officers as possible right now,\" he added. \n \nThe United States denied entry to 109 travelers heading to the country at the time the ruling was signed, a Department of Homeland Security official said. The agency would not say how many of them were sent already home and how many were detained. \n \nACLU Executive Director Anthony D. Romero praised the ruling, saying \"our courts today worked as they should as bulwarks against government abuse or unconstitutional policies and orders. On week one, Donald Trump suffered his first loss in court.\" \n \nLee Gelernt, deputy director of the ACLU's Immigrants' Rights Project, who argued the case, said the ruling \"preserves the status quo and ensures that people who have been granted permission to be in this country are not illegally removed off U.S. soil.\" \n \nLawsuit is first challenge to executive order \n \nThe class-action lawsuit is the first legal challenge to Trump's controversial executive order, which indefinitely suspends admissions for Syrian refugees and limits the flow of other refugees into the United States by instituting what the President has called \"extreme vetting\" of immigrants. \n \nThe two Iraqis, Hameed Khalid Darweesh and Haider Sameer Abdulkaleq Alshawi, had been released by Saturday night. But lawyers for other detained travelers said in a court filing that \"dozens and dozens\" of individuals remained held at JFK. \n \nSimilar legal actions had been initiated in other states.. \n \nA federal court in Washington state issued a stay forbidding travelers being detained there from being sent back to their home country. \n \nA federal court in Virginia has issued a temporary restraining order saying several dozen permanent residents returning from trips abroad should have access to lawyers while they are being detained at Dulles International Airport and these residents cannot be removed from the United States for seven days. \n \nTrump's order, signed Friday, bars travel from seven Muslim-majority countries, including Iraq, to the US for 90 days. It also suspends the US Refugee Admissions Program for 120 days until it is reinstated \"only for nationals of countries for whom\" members of Trump's Cabinet deem can be properly vetted. \n \nReleased under special circumstances \n \nAccording to court papers, both Darweesh and Alshawi were legally allowed to come into the US but were detained in accordance with Trump's order. \n \nDarweesh, who worked as an interpreter for the US during the Iraq War, was released from detention early Saturday afternoon. \n \n\"America is the land of freedom,\" he told reporters at the airport shortly after his release. \"America is the greatest nation.\" \n \nA source with knowledge of the case confirmed Darweesh will be allowed into the US due to provisions in Trump's order that allow the State and Homeland Security departments to admit individuals into the US on a case-by-case base for certain reasons, including when the person is already in transit and it would cause undue hardship and would not pose a threat to the security of the US. \n \nThe suit said Darweesh held a special immigrant visa, which he was granted the day of Trump's inauguration on January 20, due to his work for the US government from 2003 to 2013. \n \nAlshawi was released Saturday night, according to his attorney, Mark Doss. \n \nRep. Nydia Velazquez, D-New York, who had arrived at JFK by early Saturday afternoon to try and secure the release of the two Iraqis, railed against Trump's order and pledged continued action. \n \n\"This should not happen in America,\" Velazquez said following Darweesh's release. \"One by one, street by street, if we have to go to court, we will fight this anyplace, anywhere.\" \n \n'The executive order is unlawful' \n \nThe lawsuit said the US granted Alshawi a visa earlier this month to meet with his wife and son, whom the US already granted refugee status for her association with the US military. \n \nThe lawyers for the two men called for a hearing because they maintain the detention of people with valid visas is illegal. \n \n\"Because the executive order is unlawful as applied to petitioners, their continued detention based solely on the executive order violates their Fifth Amendment procedural and substantive due process rights,\" the lawyers argue in court papers. \n \nCourt papers said Customs and Border Protection authorities did not allow the lawyers to meet with the men and told them to try reaching Trump. Velázquez and fellow New York Democratic Rep. Jerrold Nadler said they attempted to speak to Darweesh and Alshawi at JFK's Terminal 4 earlier Saturday but were denied. \n \n\"When Mr. Darweesh's attorneys approached CBP requesting to speak with Mr. Darweesh, CBP indicated that they were not the ones to talk to about seeing their client. When the attorneys asked, 'Who is the person to talk to?' the CBP agents responded, 'Mr. President. Call Mr. Trump,'\" the court papers read. \n \nDoss, an attorney with the International Refugee Assistance Project, told CNN his clients knew they had to get to the US as soon as possible so they boarded the first flight they could. \n \nThe two men had been allowed to make phone calls. They do not know each other, and it is unclear if they were held together or separately, or if they were kept in a holding cell, according to Doss. \n \n\"Our courageous plaintiff and countless others risked their lives helping US service members in Iraq. Trump's order puts those who have helped us in harm's way by denying them the safe harbor they have been promised in the United States,\" said Karen Tumlin, the legal director of the NILC. \n \nThe lawsuit was earlier reported by The New York Times. \n \nLegality questioned \n \nTrump's executive order, titled \"Protection Of The Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into The United States,\" makes good on his longtime campaign promise to tighten borders and halt certain refugees from entering the United States. \n \nThe countries impacted are Iran, Iraq, Syria, Sudan, Libya, Yemen and Somalia, according to a White House official. It also caps the total number of refugees admitted into the United States during the 2017 fiscal year at 50,000, down more than half from the current level of 110,000. \n \n\"I am establishing new vetting measures to keep radical Islamic terrorists out of the United States of America,\" Trump said during the signing at the Pentagon. \"We don't want them here.\" \n \nAn administration official told CNN if a person has a valid visa to enter the US but is a citizen of one of the seven countries under the temporary travel ban, then the person cannot come into the US. If the person landed after the order was signed Friday afternoon, then the person would be detained and put back on a flight to their country of citizenship. \n \nDepartment of Homeland Security officials acknowledged people who were in the air would be detained upon arrival and put back on a plane to their home country. An official was not able to provide numbers of how many have already been detained. \n \nAfter the federal orders were issued, the department said it \"will continue to enforce all of the president's Executive Orders in a manner that ensures the safety and security of the American people. \n \n\"The president's Executive Orders remain in place-prohibited travel will remain prohibited, and the U.S. government retains its right to revoke visas at any time if required for national security or public safety. \n \n\"The president's Executive Order affects a minor portion of international travelers, and is a first step towards reestablishing control over America's borders and national security.\" \n \nCNN's Kevin Bohn, Ellie Kaufman, Patricia Pedraza, Sheena Jones, Mohammed Tawfeeq, Rachel Crane, Chris Welch and Sarah Jorgensen contributed to this report.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US security news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Iraq news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Breaking News: Homeland Security to comply with orders not to deport travelers 19 MIN","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Lancaster","zipCode":"17603","state":"Pennsylvania","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Lancaster","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"WGAL Channel","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169674001","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"166"},"name":"WGAL Channel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.wgal.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198473706","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:44:01Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Writers\u2019 Conference is scheduled for March 4 at the Terrebonne Parish Main Library in Houma. \n \nThis all-day event will feature writing sessions for fiction, nonfiction and children\u2019s writers. Session topics include self-publishing, getting your novel published, writing better fiction, poetry and other sessions to improve writing. \n \nSpeakers include Jeff Lindsay, writer of the \"Dexter\" series on Showtime; New York Times bestseller Rachel Caine, author of the paranormal \"Morganville Vampire,\" \"Revivalist\" and \"Weather Warden\" series. Marvel Comic writer Roland Paris will present sessions, along with romance writer Farrah Rochon. Rochon writes the \"New York Sabers,\" \"Holmes\" and Camp Firefly series. She is a USA Today best-selling author. \n \nOther writers include Nicholas Mainieri, M.O. Walsh, Johnnie Bernhard, Poet David Middleton and young adult favorite Ashley Elston. \n \nKeynote speaker will be New York Times Bestseller Lisa Unger. She is the author of 14 novels, including \u201cBeautiful Lies,\u201d \u201cInk and Bone,\u201d \u201cCrazy Love You\u201d and \u201cFragile.\u201d \n \nSubmissions are being accepted for the fiction contest, which has a $10 entry fee, and the poetry contest, which has a $5 entry fee. The fiction and poetry submissions are due by Feb. 1. There will also be a \u201cFirst Page Contest.\u201d \n \nRegistration is open, and the conference fee is $35 in advance, $45 at the door. Call Jessi Suire at 850-5301 for information. \n \nLearn about wills \n \nAt 6 p.m. Jan. 30, Lawyers for Libraries will hold a session at Houma's Main Library on living wills and healthcare power of attorney. Local attorney Mary Riviere will speak and answer questions. \n \nWorkout Wednesdays \n \nWorkout Wednesdays started this month at the North Terrebonne Branch. The low-stress workouts last under one hour. The class will follow Leslie Sanson\u2019s walking DVDs. Please bring water. The classes start at 5:30 p.m. every Wednesday. \n \nHistory lessons \n \nA RELIC -- Readings in Literature and Culture -- series will begin March 13 and continue weekly until April 17 at the North Branch in Gray. The sessions will be from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. The topic will be \u201cThe Supreme Court and its Chief Justices.\u201d The justices to be discussed are John Marshall, Morrison Waite, Edward Douglas White, Fred Vinson, and Earl Warren. \n \nRegistration is now open;  Suire at 850-5301. Paul Leslie will be the facilitator. Reading material will no longer include books, but paper copies of articles and chapters. This program is funded by the Friends of the Library. \n \nEnglish as a Second Language Classes \n \nThe Main Library staff is offering English as a Second Language classes from 6:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. on Thursdays. The classes are for all ages whose native language is Spanish. \n \nPedro tournament \n \nA Pedro tournament will be held at 2 p.m. Feb. 2 at the Main Library. Teens and adults are invited. \n \nBlack History Month \n \nThe Main Library will show the PBS program \u201cMany Rivers to Cross\u201d by Henry Louis Gates from 6:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m. on Mondays during February in the distance-education classroom. \n \nLincoln Center screening \n \nAt 3 p.m. on February 5 at the North Branch, a Lincoln Center free screening of the Heritage Blues Trio will be shown. The trio members are from the Grammy nominated Heritage Blues Orchestra. Members performing will be guitarist and harmonica player Bill Sims Jr., vocalist and percussionist Chaney Sims and guitarist and vocalist Junior Mack. \n \nVirtual reality demos \n \nWant to ride a roller coaster without leaving your chair or go scuba diving without getting wet? The Main Library will host a virtual reality demonstration at 4 p.m. Feb. 4. Try out the virtual glasses with pre-loaded apps. The demos are first-come, first-served. \n \n-- Mary Cosper LeBoeuf is director of the Terrebonne Parish Library System. ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Mary Cosper LeBoeuf"},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: latest","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"Entertainment: book news","group":"Entertainment"}],"title":"Attention, readers and writers: This conference is for you","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Lafourche","zipCode":"70301","state":"Louisiana","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Thibodaux","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daily Comet","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169668587","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"132"},"name":"Daily Comet","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Lifestyle","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.dailycomet.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198474279","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:01:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:44:01Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
