KENNEDY INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, NY \u2014 Sahar, a recent Stony Brook University graduate whose Iranian parents flew into JFK to visit her this weekend, showed up to the airport Saturday morning with the hope of hugging and kissing her mom and dad after three years of separation. \n \nInstead, 32-year-old Sahar was informed by federal agents that her parents had been taken into custody \u2014 and would be forced to return to Iran on the next available flight. \n \n\"They won't allow me to see them,\" she said. \"I haven't seen them in years. I just want to see them, just for one minute. Just behind a window \u2014 anything.\" \n \nUPDATE, Sunday, 2:15 a.m.: Hours ago, a federal judge in Brooklyn temporarily halted Trump's Muslim immigration ban . However, as of this time, Sahar's parents are still detained. And she was just informed over the phone by a Customs and Border Protection officer that no decision will be made about their status until morning. \n  \nTrump signed an executive order Friday that bans people from certain countries from entering the U.S. for 90 days. The countries were not named in the order, but several news outlets reported them as Iraq, Libya, Syria, Somalia, Iran, Yemen and Sudan. The order also indefinitely suspends the entry of Syrian refugees and bans the resettlement of refugees from any country for four months. \n\n \nVahideh Rasekhi , another Stony Brook University student currently working toward her PhD in linguistics, was also detained Saturday at JFK on her way back from spending winter break in Iran, according to the International Refugee Assistance Project. \n \nRasekhi and Sahar's parents were among approximately 20 immigrants and refugees detained at JFK by 6 p.m. Saturday , attorneys with the organization said. \n \nSahar \u2014 who did not want to provide her full name or show her face in a photo, for fear she would likewise be targeted by the Trump administration \u2014 broke down in tears in the Terminal 1 arrivals hall Saturday evening. \n \n\"If I'd known this would happen, I would have never come\" to the U.S., she said. \"I thought it was a democracy.\" \n \nIf Trump's new policy continues to prevent her from seeing her parents, Sahar said she and her husband will leave America. \n \n\"We'll have to go to a different country to find freedom,\" she said. \n \nSahar's parents secured two tourist visas back in October after \"an extensive security process,\" Urooj Khan, a volunteer attorney working on the family's case, told Patch. \n \nHowever, their visas were apparently voided as soon as Trump signed his order, while Sahar's parents were still in flight. \n \nSahar has not been allowed to speak with her mom and dad while they've been in Customs and Border Protection custody at JFK. She said she hopes they're not feeling afraid. \n \nAttorneys with the International Refugee Assistance Project filed a last-minute habeas petition on behalf of Sahar's parents in Brooklyn federal court Saturday \u2014 as they did for more than a dozen immigrants and refugees also detained at JFK, including Rasekhi \u2014 hoping court officials might intervene. By 6:30 p.m., though, there was still no answer. \n\n \nTurkish Airlines informed the attorneys that Sahar's parents would be placed on an 11 p.m. flight back to Iran. \n \nPhotos by Simone Wilson/Patch","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Simone Wilson"},"topics":[{"name":"New York metro area news","group":"US regional"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Iran news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"College Student's Iranian Parents Detained At JFK: 'I Just Want To See Them,' She Sobs","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Kings","zipCode":"11215","state":"New York","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Brooklyn","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Carroll Gardens Patch","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"172080913","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Carroll Gardens Patch","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.carrollgardens.patch.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://linguistics.stonybrook.edu/students/vahideh.rasekhi"],"sequenceId":"695198917001","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-28T23:42:27Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:47:56Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"https://cdn20.patch.com/users/22859565/20170128/064224/styles/T600x450/public/article_images/unnamed-1485645607-4672.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

The Operational Services Division offers this workshop for those interested in learning about the benefits of becoming a supplier diversity certified business. Attending this program is required for minority-owned, woman-owned, veteran-owned or disadvantaged business enterprise certification applications. Participants can learn about certification criteria and how to begin the process. SDO-certified business will become more marketable to government entities and create business to business partnerships. This event will be free. \n \nJohnson Compounding & Wellness to host lecture \n \nJohnson Compounding & Wellness will host a free lecture featuring Dr. Alex Bingham from the Rothfeld Center for Integrative Medicine from 7-9 p.m. Feb. 8 at Johnson Compounding & Wellness, 577 Main St., Waltham. Bingham will lead an interactive discussion on small intestinal bacterial overgrowth, during which attendees will learn about the symptoms of this condition, how it compares to IBS, and how it is diagnosed and treated. Hair Cuttery has a location at 723 Main St., Waltham. \n \nMassBay to host auto competition \n \nMassBay Community College, of Ashland, will host this year\u2019s Massachusetts State Automobile Dealers Association competition for high school students at 9 a.m. Feb. 4 in the MassBay Community College Automotive Technology Center, 270 Eliot St. High school junior and senior students from across Massachusetts will compete in a written and hands-on automotive technology competition to try and land the top spot to advancing to the National Automotive Technology Competition held at New York\u2019s International Auto Show in April. In January, 80 automotive education students from 12 Massachusetts high schools participated in the written part of the competition. The results of both the written test and the hands-on challenge will be combined and the top high school senior two-person team will advance to the national competition to represent Massachusetts. This automotive competition gives area high school students the opportunity to test their skill and ability in automotive technology against some of the best high school automotive students in Massachusetts. The hands-on portion of this competition is performed on a GM Cadillac SRX vehicle to test student\u2019s expertise in diagnostics and systemwide automotive knowledge and is based on what students might face as they work in a real world automotive environment. Students are competing not only to advance to the national competition in New York, but they are also are vying for scholarships and prizes. UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"787","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395955554&p=2kx&v=1&x=kIpur3vPVsl3MoOJXpvQrQ","id":"29395955554","content":"Lance Shearer, Daily News Correspondent  Published 5:48 p.m. ET Jan. 28, 2017 | Updated 4 minutes ago \n      \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n  \nBuy Photo \n    \nAutoplay \n \nShow Thumbnails \n \nShow Captions \n  Last Slide Next Slide     Buy Photo  \nBob Warden enjoys a hot bowl of soup during the annual Empty Bowls Naples fundraiser in Naples, Fla., Saturday, Jan. 28, 2017. A record-setting 3,000 bowls, all created by volunteers, will hold 50 varieties of hot soups contributed by local restaurants and country clubs for the annual Empty Bowls Naples fundraiser Saturday to feed Southwest Florida's hungry. (Photo: Logan Newell/Special to The Naples Daily News) Buy Photo \n  \nCambier Park was full Saturday for Empty Bowls Naples. \n \nAt the Harry Chapin Food Bank fundraiser, participants paid $20 for a keepsake bowl and then sampled soups from 50 local restaurants. \n \nAfter the crowd went through 3,300 handmade bowls that had been fired and painted throughout the year, event organizers had to dig up 300 more bowls. Then, they ran out of bowls altogether. \n \nSoup lovers thronged to the park, at the edge of the Fifth Avenue South shopping district, giving the tree-shaded area in front of the bandstand the look of a rock concert \u2014 except everyone was sipping soup, comparing soups and considering which soup to try next. \n \nPeople lined up for blocks, hours before Empty Bowls opened at 11 a.m., to be among the first to choose their bowls and their soups. \n \nAfter first tastings, long lines formed in front of the kettles of the most popular soups, and volunteers kept busy dishing them up. \n \nJust after noon, Texas Tony\u2019s three-meat chili was the first to run out. \n \nJan Maria Jagush, a winter resident from Connecticut, was next in line when highly rated roasted artichoke soup from Talis Park was the next to go, but she took it in stride. \n \n\u201cThis is a great event,\" she said. \"I\u2019m all in favor of organizations that give it all back, that use all of the proceeds to help people.\u201d \n \nWith 100 percent of the soups donated and labor provided by volunteers, all the money raised goes to help the work of the Harry Chapin Food Bank, the largest hunger relief organization in Southwest Florida. The food bank feeds 28,000 people each week. \n \nEmpty Bowls co-chairwoman Betsy Dawson said the food bank uses its connections and purchasing power to leverage every dollar raised into $8 worth of food. Last year, the event raised $97,000, and Dawson said she was confident the goal of $100,000 this year would be surpassed. \n \nThere were 50 varieties of soup. \n \nAll of the French bread was donated and served by Panera Bread, which baked 400 baguettes, enough to make 4,600 chunks of bread, to help participants sop up every bit of soup. \n \nLocal artists, including Muffy Clark Gill, made one-of-a-kind ceramics that were sold in a silent auction, bringing in additional thousands of dollars. \n \n\u201cFriends of Empty Bowls\u201d wore miniature ceramic tasting bowls around their necks, and a volunteer crew that included many area high school students worked hard to keep everything running smoothly. \n \nVolunteer Ron Kezeske of the Naples Jaycees even showed up with a laser thermometer and stopped volunteers about to serve from one refilled kettle. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s 130 degrees, but it needs to be 135,\u201d he said. \n \nIn front of the stage, a dozen potters threw new bowls on the wheel, getting a start on next year\u2019s bowls. \n \nOne of the potters, Danny Ripka, has been making bowls for the event for nine years. Ripka said he still gets a thrill when someone comes by eating soup out of one of his creations. \n \nThe restaurants furnished their soups in disposable paper bowls, so each soup could be tasted on its own. \n  Buy Photo  \nDanny Ripka makes a bowl during the annual Empty Bowls Naples fundraiser in Naples, Fla., Saturday, Jan. 28, 2017. A record-setting 3,000 bowls, all created by volunteers, will hold 50 varieties of hot soups contributed by local restaurants and country clubs for the annual Empty Bowls Naples fundraiser Saturday to feed Southwest Florida's hungry.  (Photo: Logan Newell/Special to The Naples Daily News) \n   \nBut the souvenir ceramic bowls are reminders that thousands of people in Southwest Florida, many of them children, go to sleep every night without enough food, organizers said. \n \nFor additional information on Empty Bowls or to contribute financially to the Harry Chapin Food Bank, call 239-334-7007 or see harrychapinfoodbank.org. \n  Buy Photo  \nAn assortment of bowls are seen during the annual Empty Bowls Naples fundraiser in Naples, Fla., Saturday, Jan. 28, 2017. transparency, privacy, and interoperability; collaboration between people and AI systems; and the trustworthiness, reliability, and robustness of the technology,\u201d according to a statement. \n \nInternet giants have been investing heavily in creating software to help machines think more like people, ideally acting as virtual assistants who get to know users and perhaps even anticipate needs. \n \nSpaceX founder and Tesla chief executive Elon Musk in 2015 took part in creating nonprofit research company OpenAI devoted to developing artificial intelligence that will help people and not hurt them. \n \nMusk found himself in the middle of a technology world controversy by holding firm that AI could turn on humanity and be its ruin instead of a salvation. \n \nA concern expressed by Musk was that highly advanced artificial intelligence would be left to its own devices, or in the hands of a few people, to the detriment of civilization as a whole. \n \nPeople joining tech company executives on the Partnership board included Dario Amodei of Open AI along with members of the American Civil Liberties Union; TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1661","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395956219&p=2kx&v=1&x=8ez2Tyb-28ye5IGcS-hqVA","id":"29395956219","content":"(CNN) -- The Department of Homeland Security said on Sunday it will comply with federal orders not to deport detained travelers. \n  \n  \nThis comes after a federal judge in New York granted an emergency stay Saturday night for citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries who have already arrived in the US and those who are in transit, and who hold valid visas, ruling they cannot be removed from the US. \n \nThat move limited part of President Donald Trump's executive order barring citizens from those countries from entering the US for the next 90 days. \n \nSimilar legal rulings were made in Virginia and Washington state after the New York ruling was made. \n \n\"The Department of Homeland Security will comply with judicial orders; faithfully enforce our immigration laws, and implement the president's Executive Orders to ensure that those entering the United States do not pose a threat to our country or the American people,\" the department said. \n \nOn Saturday evening, the ACLU argued in a federal court in New York for a nationwide stay that would block the deportation of all people stranded in US airports under what the group called \"President Trump's new Muslim ban.\" \n \nUS District Judge Ann Donnelly granted the stay. \n \n\"The petitioners have a strong likelihood of success in establishing that the removal of the petitioner and other similarly situated violates their due process and equal protection guaranteed by the United States Constitution,\" Donnelly wrote in her decision. \n \n\"There is imminent danger that, absent the stay of removal, there will be substantial and irreparable injury to refugees, visa-holders, and other individuals from nations subject to the January 27, 2017, Executive Order.\" \n \nThe civil rights group is representing dozens of travelers held at John F. Kennedy International Airport Friday and Saturday, including two Iraqis with ties to the US military who had been granted visas to enter the United States. \n \nThe ruling does not necessarily mean the people being held at airports across the US are going to be released, said Zachary Manfredi, from Yale's Worker and Immigrant Rights Advocacy Clinic, who helped draft the emergency stay motion. \n \n\"The judge's order is that they (lawful visa/green card holders) not be removed from the US -- it doesn't immediately order that they be released from detention,\" he told CNN. \n \n\"We are hoping that CBP (Customs and Border Patrol), now that they no longer have a reason to detain them, will release them. But it is also possible they could be transferred to (other) detention facilities.\" \n \n\"We are getting the order to as many CBP officers as possible right now,\" he added. \n \nThe United States denied entry to 109 travelers heading to the country at the time the ruling was signed, a Department of Homeland Security official said. The agency would not say how many of them were sent already home and how many were detained. \n \nACLU Executive Director Anthony D. Romero praised the ruling, saying \"our courts today worked as they should as bulwarks against government abuse or unconstitutional policies and orders. On week one, Donald Trump suffered his first loss in court.\" \n \nLee Gelernt, deputy director of the ACLU's Immigrants' Rights Project, who argued the case, said the ruling \"preserves the status quo and ensures that people who have been granted permission to be in this country are not illegally removed off U.S. soil.\" \n \nLawsuit is first challenge to executive order \n \nThe class-action lawsuit is the first legal challenge to Trump's controversial executive order, which indefinitely suspends admissions for Syrian refugees and limits the flow of other refugees into the United States by instituting what the President has called \"extreme vetting\" of immigrants. \n \nThe two Iraqis, Hameed Khalid Darweesh and Haider Sameer Abdulkaleq Alshawi, had been released by Saturday night. But lawyers for other detained travelers said in a court filing that \"dozens and dozens\" of individuals remained held at JFK. \n \nSimilar legal actions had been initiated in other states.. \n \nA federal court in Washington state issued a stay forbidding travelers being detained there from being sent back to their home country. \n \nA federal court in Virginia has issued a temporary restraining order saying several dozen permanent residents returning from trips abroad should have access to lawyers while they are being detained at Dulles International Airport and these residents cannot be removed from the United States for seven days. \n \nTrump's order, signed Friday, bars travel from seven Muslim-majority countries, including Iraq, to the US for 90 days. It also suspends the US Refugee Admissions Program for 120 days until it is reinstated \"only for nationals of countries for whom\" members of Trump's Cabinet deem can be properly vetted. \n \nReleased under special circumstances \n \nAccording to court papers, both Darweesh and Alshawi were legally allowed to come into the US but were detained in accordance with Trump's order. \n \nDarweesh, who worked as an interpreter for the US during the Iraq War, was released from detention early Saturday afternoon. \n \n\"America is the land of freedom,\" he told reporters at the airport shortly after his release. \"America is the greatest nation.\" \n \nA source with knowledge of the case confirmed Darweesh will be allowed into the US due to provisions in Trump's order that allow the State and Homeland Security departments to admit individuals into the US on a case-by-case base for certain reasons, including when the person is already in transit and it would cause undue hardship and would not pose a threat to the security of the US. \n \nThe suit said Darweesh held a special immigrant visa, which he was granted the day of Trump's inauguration on January 20, due to his work for the US government from 2003 to 2013. \n \nAlshawi was released Saturday night, according to his attorney, Mark Doss. \n \nRep. Nydia Velazquez, D-New York, who had arrived at JFK by early Saturday afternoon to try and secure the release of the two Iraqis, railed against Trump's order and pledged continued action. \n \n\"This should not happen in America,\" Velazquez said following Darweesh's release. \"One by one, street by street, if we have to go to court, we will fight this anyplace, anywhere.\" \n \n'The executive order is unlawful' \n \nThe lawsuit said the US granted Alshawi a visa earlier this month to meet with his wife and son, whom the US already granted refugee status for her association with the US military. \n \nThe lawyers for the two men called for a hearing because they maintain the detention of people with valid visas is illegal. \n \n\"Because the executive order is unlawful as applied to petitioners, their continued detention based solely on the executive order violates their Fifth Amendment procedural and substantive due process rights,\" the lawyers argue in court papers. \n \nCourt papers said Customs and Border Protection authorities did not allow the lawyers to meet with the men and told them to try reaching Trump. Velázquez and fellow New York Democratic Rep. Jerrold Nadler said they attempted to speak to Darweesh and Alshawi at JFK's Terminal 4 earlier Saturday but were denied. \n \n\"When Mr. Darweesh's attorneys approached CBP requesting to speak with Mr. Darweesh, CBP indicated that they were not the ones to talk to about seeing their client. When the attorneys asked, 'Who is the person to talk to?' the CBP agents responded, 'Mr. President. Call Mr. Trump,'\" the court papers read. \n \nDoss, an attorney with the International Refugee Assistance Project, told CNN his clients knew they had to get to the US as soon as possible so they boarded the first flight they could. \n \nThe two men had been allowed to make phone calls. They do not know each other, and it is unclear if they were held together or separately, or if they were kept in a holding cell, according to Doss. \n \n\"Our courageous plaintiff and countless others risked their lives helping US service members in Iraq. Trump's order puts those who have helped us in harm's way by denying them the safe harbor they have been promised in the United States,\" said Karen Tumlin, the legal director of the NILC. \n \nThe lawsuit was earlier reported by The New York Times. \n \nLegality questioned \n \nTrump's executive order, titled \"Protection Of The Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into The United States,\" makes good on his longtime campaign promise to tighten borders and halt certain refugees from entering the United States. \n \nThe countries impacted are Iran, Iraq, Syria, Sudan, Libya, Yemen and Somalia, according to a White House official. It also caps the total number of refugees admitted into the United States during the 2017 fiscal year at 50,000, down more than half from the current level of 110,000. \n \n\"I am establishing new vetting measures to keep radical Islamic terrorists out of the United States of America,\" Trump said during the signing at the Pentagon. \"We don't want them here.\" \n \nAn administration official told CNN if a person has a valid visa to enter the US but is a citizen of one of the seven countries under the temporary travel ban, then the person cannot come into the US. If the person landed after the order was signed Friday afternoon, then the person would be detained and put back on a flight to their country of citizenship. \n \nDepartment of Homeland Security officials acknowledged people who were in the air would be detained upon arrival and put back on a plane to their home country. An official was not able to provide numbers of how many have already been detained. \n \nAfter the federal orders were issued, the department said it \"will continue to enforce all of the president's Executive Orders in a manner that ensures the safety and security of the American people. \n \n\"The president's Executive Orders remain in place-prohibited travel will remain prohibited, and the U.S. government retains its right to revoke visas at any time if required for national security or public safety. \n \n\"The president's Executive Order affects a minor portion of international travelers, and is a first step towards reestablishing control over America's borders and national security.\" \n \nCNN's Kevin Bohn, Ellie Kaufman, Patricia Pedraza, Sheena Jones, Mohammed Tawfeeq, Rachel Crane, Chris Welch and Sarah Jorgensen contributed to this report.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Real estate news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US security news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Iraq news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Breaking News: Homeland Security to comply with orders not to deport travelers 23 MIN","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Cumberland","zipCode":"04101","state":"Maine","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Portland","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"WMTW","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169659817","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"89"},"name":"WMTW","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","RealEstate"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.wmtw.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198929313","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:48:05Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

(Photo: Justin Lane, EPA) \n  \nSAN FRANCISCO \u2014 Hundreds of outraged demonstrators converged on San Francisco International Airport Saturday afternoon, in defiance of President Trump's executive order banning refugees and foreign citizens from seven predominantly Muslim countries entry into the U.S. \n \nWaving signs reading \u201cMy Grandparents Were One of the Lucky Ones\" and \"One Earth, One People, One Love,\u201d they chanted in full throat, \"You put a wall, we tear it down\" and \"Never again!\" \n \nAs the crowd swelled to as many as 1,000, some protesters spilled onto the road that circled the international terminal, briefly blocking access for cars attempting to get to the terminal. Organizers extended the peaceful protest. \n \nGoogle co-founder Sergey Brin, an immigrant himself, and California Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom were among the protesters. \n \nSan Francisco Mayor Ed Lee issued a statement, calling the ban \"disgusting.\" \n \n\"As the son of Chinese immigrants, I am disgusted by the President\u2019s Executive Order to target the Muslim community and ban immigrants from entering the United States,\" the mayor said. \n \nThe crowd only began to thin after a federal court in Brooklyn issued a temporary emergency stay halting Trump's order late Saturday. But it remained large, and boisterous, deep into the night. \n \n\"It was chaos,\" Buzz Frahn, an immigration attorney from Palo Alto, Calif., said of the demonstration. \n \nFrahn was one of dozens of lawyers who rushed to the airport to assist families waiting for members to clear customs. He said he was aware of at least five travelers detained who are Iranian. \n \n\u201cMy parents came from Iran right before I was born,\u201d protester Samin Nosrat, 37, of Berkeley told the San Francisco Chronicle . \u201cI am the child of refugees. If they were not allowed to come here, I do not know what my life would look like ... this is unacceptable.\u201d \n \nAt JFK International Airport, a Stanford University graduate student, a legal permanent resident of the U.S., was detained for several hours and handcuffed briefly after returning from a research trip to Sudan, according to an email issued by the university on the immigration ban obtained by USA TODAY. \n \nThe San Francisco Bay Area isn't just a bastion of liberal politics, but also the home of Silicon Valley, which is dependent on a pipeline of technical talent from overseas. \n \nIn a staff memo, Google CEO Sundar Pichai said the ban affects nearly 200 of the company's staff. \n \nChief executives of Apple, Microsoft, Uber and Netflix denounced the policy, which would compromise their employees working legally here and create barriers from them bringing talent to the U.S. \n \nWhile the ban applied to refugees, human rights groups have reported that green card holders \u2014 legal permanent residents of the United States who have the right to live and work here \u2014 have also been stopped. \n   \nUSA TODAY \n \nTrump immigration ban sends shockwaves through tech \n  \n\"The Executive Order's humanitarian and economic impact is real and upsetting,\" Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey said in a tweet. \"We benefit from what refugees and immigrants bring to the U.S.\" \n \nThen there is the historical perspective, attorney Frahn said. \n \n\"One sign really stood out,\" he said. \"It said Anne Frank and her family were denied entry as refugees to the U.S. in 1941. That speaks volume about this ban.\" \n \nContributing: Elizabeth Weise in San Francisco. \n \nFollow USA TODAY San Francisco Bureau Chief Jon Swartz @jswartz on Twitter. \n \nRead or Share this story: http://usat.ly/2jJghIw","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Jon Swartz"},"topics":[{"name":"Airline industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"San Francisco Bay Area news","group":"US regional"},{"name":"Political unrest news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Internet latest","group":"Internet"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"\"You put a wall, we tear it down\": 1,000 protest ban at SF airport","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Wood","zipCode":"54449","state":"Wisconsin","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Marshfield","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Marshfield News Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169686474","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Marshfield News Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Global","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.marshfieldnewsherald.com","publisher":"Gannett"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2017/01/28/google-ceo-speaks-out-against-trump-refugee-ban/97182748/","http://twitter.com/jswartz","http://usat.ly/2jJghIw"],"sequenceId":"695198937727","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:48:09Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Organisers claim this a record number of the little dogs in the one place at the one time. \n\nMark Ellis, the organiser of Sunday's Werriwa Wiener Dash at the Bungendore Show, believes the turnout of 154 dachshunds for the event constitutes a world record for the number of the sausage dogs in one place at one time.\n\n\"We had miniatures, long hairs, short hairs, standards and wire hairs,\" he said. \"They came from all over; some even travelled from Melbourne.\n\nWhile Mr Ellis wasn't able to engage the attention of the people from Guinness, who ruled the record being sought was too \"specialised\" to interest them, he is happy to claim the record with any other contenders needing to prove him wrong.\n\nAlthough the quirky event, which has captured the imagination of dachshund lovers from across NSW and the ACT, is only in its second year it has already become one of the feature events of the Bungendore Show.\n\nThis year's dash winner was Buddy, owned by Jacqueline Winzenberg of Page in the ACT. Buddy's award was presented by NSW Deputy Premier and local member John Barilaro.\n\nOne hundred and twenty seven dogs turned up for the inaugural event in 2016.\n\nBungendore Show, which was first held in the 1840s, has gone from strength to strength in recent decades, this year's showgirl, Hanna Darmody, 22, said.\n\nMs Darmody, whose family own a Bungendore butchery, said she could recall helping with the catering at the show as a toddler almost 20 years ago.\n\n\"I've seen the event grow as the town has grown,\" she said. \"It is a great bridge between country and city; the showgirl competition is a good way to get young people involved and promotes opportunities in agriculture.\"\n\nShow organisers said this year's event, which enjoyed the best weather conditions in three years, was an unqualified success with more than 2000 people passing through the gates before lunch.\n\nIn addition to the usual attractions in the show ring and the pavilions and the dachshund dash, the 2017 event offered visitors a chance to get a close look at the Anzac Centennial 18 pounder gun.\n\nThe World War I-era weapon, which also saw service during World War II,was restored by the Royal Australian Artillery Company in conjunction with veteran coach builder Jim Frecklington. everyone called it retirement and a comeback and everyone like that,\" he said. \n \n\"I knew I had more cycling left in me. \n \n\"It just took time, it just took a bit of a break - it took a bit of time away, which I hadn't had since I was 12. \n \n\"That was probably a bit of my downfall, not managing outside, off the bike.\" \n \nMeyer initially returned on the track - he is a six-time world champion on the boards - but this month he has also starred in the composite national road team. \n \nMade up mainly of developing riders, they won the teams category at the Tour Down Under. \n \nThey were the only non-WorldTour team in the field. \n \nSunday's result again showed that Meyer is back, but it remains to be seen what he does once the Australian season ends. \n \nHis immediate aims are next week's Herald Sun Tour and then the world track championships. \n \n\"That's the question everyone asks me actually at the moment and I don't think I have an exact answer,\" he said. \n \n\"I'm just taking it as it comes now. \n \n\"It might be a bit of national team stuff, it might be signing with a team, at the moment I'm just really enjoying it, getting back out there and having a crack.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Cameron Meyer stars in return to cycling","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","countryCode":"AU","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"GWN7 - {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395957740","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SICK LEAVE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"WOUNDS & INJURIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DRIVER BEHAVIOR","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"DISEASES & DISORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"HEART DISEASE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"SMOKING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"ROAD TRANSPORTATION SAFETY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"OVER-THE-COUNTER DRUGS","domains":["IND"],"score":"60"},{"name":"DIABETES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"STROKES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"}],"wordCount":"566","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395957740&p=2kx&v=1&x=9LaUHb7lq2jPAJTSoR6w7Q","id":"29395957740","content":"We\u2019ve all been there from time to time. You toss and turn, look at the clock and inevitably wake up feeling depleted. It makes it tough to stay awake during the day and focus on important tasks. Sleeplessness is a common problem in our busy society, and an ongoing lack of sleep can impact every part of a person\u2019s life. \n \nA good night\u2019s sleep helps the mind and body in many ways including avoiding excessive daytime fatigue, staying alert and focused, and strengthening the immune system, which also leads to better overall health, less sick days, and more productivity. \n \nA lack of good sleep can pack a host of consequences including negatively impacting decision making and memory retention abilities, decrease in reaction time, irritability, weight gain and general physical stress on the body which can increase the risk of heart disease, stroke and diabetes. \n \nLack of sleep can also be dangerous for others, not just the person dealing directly with the issue. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, sleepy drivers cause more than 100,000 crashes each ear. Of those, 40,000 result in injuries, with 1,550 deaths. It only further highlights the importance of a good night\u2019s sleep. \n \nIf you need help to remedy a lack of quality sleep, here are a few suggestions: \n \n» Get into a bedtime routine that occurs at the same time every day. Your body will automatically begin to \u201cget sleepy\u201d if you go to bed at the same time every night. \n \n» Exercise during the day. Get at least 20-30 minutes of vigorous exercise daily. But don\u2019t exercise too close to bedtime. It\u2019s best to exercise five to six hours before bedtime. \n \n» Try not to nap during the day. If you must take a nap, limit it to no more than 20 minutes. \n \n» Avoid stimulants like smoking or drinking coffee within five or six hours from when you want to go to bed.  Contrary to what you might think, alcohol can disrupt sleep as well. While it may cause you to fall asleep initially, it doesn\u2019t allow for the more restful phases of sleep, not to mention that you may also have to get up in the night to use the bathroom. \n \n» Create a meditative and relaxing environment in your bedroom that is quiet and dark, and use the time getting ready for bed to calm your mind. This means that it is best to not have a television in the room. Also pick another room to charge your cell phone at night such as the kitchen or living room. \n \nIf you\u2019ve tried most, if not all, of these already and you are still struggling with fatigue from poor sleep, medication is rarely the best option to get a better night\u2019s sleep. Even over-the-counter medications have risks, especially when used regularly. If you are using medication for sleep more than a couple times a month, or if you find the suggestions above are not helping, it is worth mentioning at your next doctor\u2019s appointment. There may be something more serious at play such as sleep apnea. \n \nGetting a good night\u2019s sleep can help to improve cognitive function, increase awareness and provide more energy. A few simple tweaks to your sleeping routine could be the difference. You can learn more and download a more in-depth, interactive sleep management kit at kp.org/choosebetter . \n \n \n\u2014 Dr. Lindsey Gerdes is a family medicine physician practicing at the Kaiser Permanente Greeley Medical Offices.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Lindsey Gerdes"},"topics":[],"title":"Gerdes: Good health and productivity begin with good sleep","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Weld","zipCode":"80631","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Greeley","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Greeley Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169669255","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1081"},"name":"Greeley Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.greeleytribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://kp.org/choosebetter"],"sequenceId":"695198945359","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:48:18Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.greeleytribune.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/G2K-KaiserColumn-GDT-032716-620x434.jpg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29351481672","companies":[{"symbol":"2462","primary":true,"name":"LIKE Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3386120004"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"OBAMA HEALTH CARE REFORM","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"PRESCRIPTION DRUG INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"87"},{"name":"POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"SOCIAL SECURITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"US REPUBLICAN PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PRIVATIZATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PRIVATELY HELD COMPANIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"HOSPITALS","domains":["IND"],"score":"69"},{"name":"PHYSICIANS & SURGEONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"87"},{"name":"POLITICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"GOVERNMENT GRANTS & SUBSIDIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US DEMOCRATIC PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"US POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DISABLED PERSONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"HEALTH INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BILLING & RECEIVABLES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"PHARMACY BENEFITS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MEDICARE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PRESCRIPTION DRUGS","domains":["IND"],"score":"61"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"806","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395957879&p=2kx&v=1&x=DUTBINNHW982fGAMDgzfJQ","id":"29395957879","content":"What will happen to Medicare? \n \nThat\u2019s not an insignificant question given the political shift in Washington. \n \nNow, with Republicans controlling the presidency and both houses of Congress, some ideas they\u2019ve been pushing for years have a chance of passing. Those ideas would drastically change the way Medicare works for those already on it and those joining in the next few years. \n \nMedicare is wildly popular, but that popularity doesn\u2019t necessarily translate into understanding of a very complex program, what\u2019s happened to it, and what may happen. Writing about Medicare for nearly 30 years and watching it evolve, I\u2019ve seen how easily Congress has already made big changes with hardly a peep from the press or the public. The same could happen again. In this column I discuss a few of those possible changes gleaned from my decades of experience covering the program. \n \nSince the election, there\u2019s been talk of \u201cvoucherizing\u201d or privatizing Medicare, an idea Republicans have been pushing for 20 years. Under a fully privatized arrangement, Medicare would no longer be social insurance like Social Security. It would be more like Obamacare with everyone eventually buying their coverage from private insurance companies. \n \nBeneficiaries would receive a sum of money, likely to be called \u201cpremium support\u201d instead of the more dire-sounding \u201cvoucher,\u201d to help buy their coverage. The amount of support and how well it would keep pace with medical inflation would be buried in the details Congress would hash out. \n \nToday, the government provides the benefits for hospital and physician care for most Medicare beneficiaries, but that could change with more privatization. There already is a lot of privatization in Medicare, and it came about step-by-step \u2013 usually with both political parties in agreement and lots of buzz words like \u201cconsumer choice\u201d to sell changes to the public. \n \nThe long steady march toward Medicare Advantage (MA) plans now used by about one-third of all beneficiaries and the prescription drug benefit are privatized insurance programs within Medicare. Seniors in MA plans give up their traditional, standardized Medicare benefits for doctor and hospital services and buy them from insurers that receive subsidies from the government. \n \nIn a totally privatized arrangement, there may be no standardized benefits, and seniors would choose from a menu of insurance company options much the way drug plans are sold today. \n \nIt\u2019s too early to say whether Congress will push for premium support this year. Democrats have already signaled they will fight back. It\u2019s more likely that other changes could slip through that would radically alter Medicare and force beneficiaries to pay a lot more for their care. \n \nOne of them is a change in the rules on balance billing: physicians charging seniors and disabled people on the program more than what Medicare will pay. Most doctors accept Medicare\u2019s payment as payment in full. Those who don\u2019t can charge patients only 15 percent more than Medicare\u2019s payment. This limit offers protection against the high balance billing charges patients with other kinds of insurance are facing. \n \nThe nominee for Secretary of Health and Human Services Tom Price is no fan of the 15 percent rule and once proposed eliminating it, which may explain why he has gotten such a strong endorsement from the American Medical Association. The AMA has called Price a leader in developing public policy to advance patient choice and \u201creduce excessive regulatory burdens.\u201d Many doctors who work with Medicare patients would like to charge as much as they want. \n \nCongress may try to shift costs another way. The objective is to reduce what the government pays for beneficiaries\u2019 care by making them pay more themselves. One solution is to combine the deductibles for hospital and physician care into one, and impose an out-of-pocket spending cap for beneficiaries still enrolled in traditional Medicare. Two-thirds of beneficiaries are. Currently no such cap exists. (Seniors in MA plans do face such caps \u2013 last year as high as $6,700.) \n \nIf seniors in the traditional program also buy a Medigap plan, it\u2019s possible they have what\u2019s called \u201cfirst dollar coverage.\u201d That means medical expenses are covered from the beginning. \n \nCongress has already begun to take that protection away. Beginning in 2020 insurers can no longer sell certain Medigap plans that provide for the first dollar coverage beneficiaries want. However, if you have such a policy, you can keep it. \n \nMedicare does face some long-term funding shortfalls, and so far the acceptable solution is to require that seniors pay more rather than raise taxes for everyone or impose cost controls with teeth, which doctors, hospitals, drug companies, and other healthcare providers don\u2019t want. I will explore all that, including negotiating pharmaceutical prices, in a future column. \n \n \n\u2014 The Rural Health News Service is funded by a grant from The Commonwealth Fund and distributed through the Nebraska Press Association Foundation, the Colorado Press Association, the South Dakota Newspaper Association and the Hoosier (Indiana) State Press Association.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Trudy Lieberman"},"topics":[{"name":"Health insurance news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"US Federal Government news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Medicaid and Medicare news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Thinking About Health: Major changes may be coming to Medicare","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Weld","zipCode":"80631","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Greeley","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Greeley Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169669255","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1081"},"name":"Greeley Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.greeleytribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198948689","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:48:19Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.greeleytribune.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Trump_Congress_40457-f6c04-620x463.jpg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:21:01Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395957947","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"WATER SUPPLY UTILITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"COMMERCIAL PROPERTY","domains":["IND"],"score":"65"},{"name":"CITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"UTILITY RATES","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"APPROVALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"BUDGETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CITY GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"WATER CONSUMPTION","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"REAL ESTATE","domains":["IND"],"score":"74"},{"name":"SANITATION DISTRICTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"715","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395957947&p=2kx&v=1&x=qrPxZIJ9eVWe_EVlbvVTaQ","id":"29395957947","content":"For the first time in 100 years, Greeley residents may have the freedom this year to water their lawns whenever they want. \n \nSince 1907, residents have faced limits on watering days \u2014 usually every other day \u2014 during warmer months. Thanks to an overhauled water budget system , residents may soon have the power to pick their days \u2014 any days; all days \u2014 so long as they stay within their budget. \n \nThe Greeley water and sewer board approved lifting the restrictions, but the city council will have to give final approval \u2014 likely next month. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s pretty simple,\u201d said Harold Evans, chairman of the city\u2019s water and sewer board. \u201cIf I\u2019m going to say you have a budget, we shouldn\u2019t tell you what days you should water.\u201d \n \nWatering freedom would run from April 1 through Oct. 31, and city officials would take a look at the results before deciding whether to keep it going in 2018. The water budget, however, is here to say. \n \nThe water budget \u2014 and watering day freedom \u2014 would apply only to residential, single-family homes. Even then, the city will restrict watering between noon-5 p.m. Businesses and other commercial property will maintain the same water rate structure as they\u2019ve had in the past. \n \nSingle-family homes account for nearly half of the city\u2019s overall water usage, making that category ripe for change. \n \nEvans said the budget, which will take effect Wednesday, is more than a decade in the making, as city officials sought to stave off the effects of a drought like the one the state saw in early 2000s . \n \nComing to consensus took a lot of work, as did developing the budget for every household. \n \nGreeley staffers mapped every plot of land in Greeley to calculate the amount of irrigable area \u2014 basically any property you have outside of your roof, sidewalk and driveway. They used that area, combined it with an assumption that every inch of that area is planted with bluegrass, and came up with a formula that spits out enough water to take care of all of that. \n \n\u201cI think it\u2019s the core of what the water budget is all about,\u201d City Manager Roy Otto said, referencing the personalized water budget. \n \nInside, the city will budget 55 gallons per person per day, with the assumption that there are three people in every household. (Call the city if you have a larger family). \n \nCity officials say the budget should provide more than enough water for most residents. In testing the program with 16,700 households, the city found 83 percent of folks stayed within budget. \n \nIf you don\u2019t, well, you\u2019ll get charged more. This year\u2019s base rate is $3.97 per 1,000 gallons, which is actually cheaper than what folks paid last year. \n \nIf you use up to 130 percent more than your budget, you\u2019ll pay $4.85 per gallon for anything over your budget. The rates go up to $6.62 and then $8.82 per 1,000 gallons from there. Just 4 percent of the pilot group of 16,700 households went that far over their budget. \n \n\u201cWe think we\u2019ve developed a program that will reward efficiency, and yet it will also provide an incentive for people who are over-watering to cut back,\u201d Evans said. \n \nFor now, the changes won\u2019t apply to businesses or other commercial property. That\u2019s a little more tricky. \n \nA typical, tiered-rate structure would have been easier. That would involve one rate for a certain amount of water, and higher rates for anything above that. \n \nFort Collins has one, and such a structure can punish homeowners with a larger lot even if those homeowners practice water conservation. \n \n\u201cWithout that work done by the staff, we would have arbitrarily penalized people for being efficient with their water just for having a larger lot,\u201d Otto said. \n \nCity officials spent so much time studying the outdoor water use because they say it\u2019s the area with the most potential for savings. In some months \u2014 particularly April and October, when people run their sprinklers more than necessary \u2014 the city as a whole could cut water usage by half or more, according to city data. \n \nAs Greeley grows toward 250,000 people by 2060, getting folks in the habit of thinking about water conservation will be key, Evans said. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s a finite supply of water in Colorado,\u201d Evans said. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to be more efficient.\u201d \n \nTyler Silvy covers city and county government for The Greeley Tribune. Reach him at tsilvy@greeleytribune.com . {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395957829","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"MENTAL HEALTH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"MENTAL HEALTH PRACTICE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SENIOR CENTERS & CLUBS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DISEASES & DISORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AGING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"IMMUNE SYSTEM DISORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"SENIOR CITIZENS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"RESIDENTIAL CARE","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LONG TERM HEALTH CARE","domains":["IND"],"score":"60"},{"name":"MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"MENTAL ILLNESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"DEPRESSION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ADULTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"PSYCHOLOGY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"FAMILY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"53"},{"name":"SOCIOLOGY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; COLORADO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"56"}],"wordCount":"674","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395957829&p=2kx&v=1&x=22MessOuKFD_QqyCnlcQdQ","id":"29395957829","content":"When Pamela Hewitt\u2019s husband, David, was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, she had to learn to be a caretaker. The disease was debilitating for both of them. \n \nShe loved her husband, but she was angry with him for taking away her life, even though she knew it wasn\u2019t his fault. She slipped into a dark depression. Her health declined, and she stopped taking care of herself. She was suicidal. \n \nDepression is not a normal part of aging, but seniors face loss and isolation for a number of reasons that put them at risk. Losing a spouse, a friend, a job, their health or their freedom because they have to care for a family member all are factors. \n \nNorth Range Behavioral Health offers a free peer counseling service to help seniors like Hewitt with those feelings of isolation or loneliness. \n \nHewitt was a professor of sociology at the University of Northern Colorado for three decades and had a background in psychology. She was open to getting help, but she had no idea what kind of impact her peer counselor, Judy Rodriguez, would have. \n \n\u201cI tell her every time I see her she saved my life,\u201d Hewitt said. \n \nPeer counselors like Rodriguez focus on seniors. They have to be 55 years old or older and they\u2019re trained to work with older adults and families as they deal with the stress of aging. \n \nRodriguez comes to Hewitt\u2019s home once per week to talk and hang out. \n \n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t sound like a psychiatrist telling you how to get your life together,\u201d Hewitt said. \u201cShe\u2019s a peer. She\u2019s a friend.\u201d \n \nHewitt\u2019s counselor encouraged her to get involved at the senior center and reconnect with others. Reconnecting with friends and others was hard, but it was worth it. \n \nJerry Kearney, manager for the peer-counseling program at North Range, said the purpose of the program is to support seniors in the community whether they\u2019re living alone, with family or in assisted living or long-term care. \n \n\u201cWe\u2019re very non-judgmental,\u201d Kearney said. \u201cWe pick them up where they\u2019re at, and we go from there.\u201d \n \nFor some reason, no one wants to admit they\u2019re old and hang out with the old people, Hewitt said. She remembered how her own mom didn\u2019t use her senior discount anywhere for many years. She also remembered how her mom would talk about not having any friends because they had died. She joked then, that her mom should make some younger friends so that they\u2019d last longer. She didn\u2019t understand how hard it was. \n \nShe gets it now. Her own friends are getting older and some have died. Friends aren\u2019t immediately replaceable, Hewitt said. \n \nHewitt\u2019s counselor has a similar sense of humor, and she\u2019d lost her husband shortly before meeting with Hewitt. \n \n\u201cJudy made me feel like I wasn\u2019t the only one,\u201d Hewitt said. \n \nBut Rodriguez also has training in psychology. She knows the vocabulary and can point out things like Hewitt\u2019s control issues, Hewitt said. It\u2019s helped her realize things about herself and work through her issues. \n \nThanks to Rodriguez\u2019s encouragement, Hewitt started writing again. She joined Writing your Life at the Senior Center. At the class, folks write about phases of their life and share parts with the class. For a long time, she\u2019d been focused on research writing for the university, but she\u2019d always loved humor writing. Hewitt decided to take a crack at making a humorous autobiography, and she had a blast. One section is called \u201cGoodbye Uterus,\u201d a funny account of a hysterectomy. \n \n\u201cTo be able to laugh at yourself is so healthy,\u201d Hewitt said. \u201cI lost that for awhile.\u201d \n \nHewitt\u2019s glad she asked for help, though she knows it\u2019s hard to do. \n \nNow, she\u2019s working with a CNA she hired on a cookbook. It\u2019s full of nutrient-packed recipes with easy-to-eat foods for people with multiple sclerosis. David can only use a spoon to eat now. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m not angry anymore,\u201d Hewitt said. \n \n \n\u2014 Kelly Ragan covers features and health for The Greeley Tribune. Have a tip or a health question you want answered? Call (970) 392-4424 or email kragan@greeleytribune.com .","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Kelly Ragan"},"topics":[{"name":"Consumer: seniors news","group":"Lifestyle"}],"title":"North Range Behavioral Health offers free peer counseling service to help seniors with feelings of isolation or loneliness","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Weld","zipCode":"80631","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Greeley","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Greeley Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169669255","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1081"},"name":"Greeley Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.greeleytribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198955988","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:48:19Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.greeleytribune.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/G2KLonelySeniors-GDT-012917-1-620x414.jpg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-28T08:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29393940041","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"GOLF","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"TOURNAMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"GOLF TOURNAMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SAN DIEGO, CA, USA; UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"PHIL MICKELSON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"50"}],"wordCount":"795","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395957831&p=2kx&v=1&x=7RHRLJ-Eo1wmqfRoSluM1A","id":"29395957831","content":"Here comes the assault on the greens, a flurry of club-wielding snipers growing more confident by the stroke. Here comes the sun-soaked window to alter scorecards and muddy leaderboards. \n\nWhen players step onto the South Course at Torrey Pines for Sunday's final round of the Farmers Insurance Open, it could be a revenge-fueled rendition of Taming of the Shrewd. \n\nThe cagey course that so often wobbles knees with ocean crosswinds and greens that test a putt's shock absorbers showed a sliver of vulnerability Saturday. \n\nTwelve players sit within two strokes of the top with a round to go. The skies, now cloudless and deep San Diego blue, cranked down the gusts. The greens and rough continue to firm up by the minute. \n\nBuckle up. The final 18 holes could be a wild ride. \n\nCharles Howell III, who shot 69 to tie for 13th, said a day positioned to deliver the best weather of the week could spark fireworks. \n\n\"You may see it give up a low number,\" he said. \n\nCareful with assumptions: The South, so stubborn that it earned the 2008 U.S. Open, never loses all its teeth and isn't anywhere close to gumming its food. The course showed, however, that forgiving weather can make it mortal. \n\nConditions bolstered the anyone-could-win equity among a field that lost world No. 1 Jason Day, No. 3 Dustin Johnson and No. 14 Rickie Fowler before the weekend arrived. \n\nThe South's bullying ways melted in the sunshine, revealing a kinder, gentler side. On Thursday, nine players carded rounds of 3-under or better on the South. On Friday, just five. On Saturday, the club ballooned to 19. \n\n\"There's no better place to play golf than Torrey Pines in weather like this,\" said Phil Mickelson, who rode the meteorological about-face to record a 68, scrambled 30 spots and climbed into a tie at 18th. \"Looking out at the ocean, the views, it's just spectacular. The course is drying out very nicely and played great.\" \n\nThe evaporating stretch of wet, cold and windy that marked the start of the Farmers allowed an army of contenders to chase red numbers. \n\nTony Finau birdied four of his final six holes to finish with a 67. The 27-year-old tied tournament co-leader Patrick Rodgers and Pat Perez for low rounds of the day and grabbed a share of third. \n\n\"It was warmer, so the ball was traveling a little better - and not as much wind,\" he said. \"It's definitely a day where you feel like you can get after it.\" \n\nThe scoring average dipped from 74-and-change on Friday to 71.62 a day later. The tournament field has not broken 72 on a Sunday at the Farmers since the course renovation leading into 2002. \n\nThe combination of calm and a building, shared confidence could threaten that number Sunday. Tournament meteorologist Willis Young said another full day of drying could make the final round \"ideal.\" \n\n\"When there's no wind, it definitely makes this place a lot easier,\" said Marc Leishman, who hovers among a knot of players tied for fifth. \"Earlier in the week, it was hard to control spin. That's getting easier. \n\n\"And it's Sunday. Guys will attack, for sure.\" \n\nMention attack and the blood pumps. Add a congested leaderboard with so many players lingering within putter's reach of a $1.2 million bankroll, and the potential for hole-by-hole drama soars. \n\nImagine the scenarios alone on No. 18, the spot that surrendered one eagle through the first two rounds - but six while parked in front of Saturday's postcard-worthy backdrop. \n\nToss in a wild card or two like Justin Rose, the second-round leader who trudged to a 73 and now tangled in an eight-way tie for fifth, and the plotlines thicken substantially. \n\nThe finish could be something only a cardiologist dares to consider. \n\n\"Something good (Sunday) is going to go a long way,\" Rose said. \"If you shoot a low score, especially with some Sunday pressure, it will be a good situation. I get to free-wheel more than they do, so it could be a good thing.\" \n\nWhen Round 3 arrived, paragliders gracefully drifted along the coast. Fans peeled away jackets. Players settled into rhythms. The Farmers changed personality in mid-stride, opening the door to even more pitch-and-putt possibility. \n\nRodgers, the co-leader with two-time champ Brandt Snedeker, said Torrey Pines rarely looks as handsome as it did Saturday. \n\n\"This is what all the players come to San Diego for, is weather days like (this),\" he said. \"The golf course was perfect.\" \n\nAggressive doesn't translate to reckless, though. \n\nPatience will pay dividends until doorways present themselves. The thing, though: There's bound to be plenty of doors cracked open during the frenetic final lap. \n\n\"I'd still never say the South Course is easy,\" Howell III said. \"But if you're comparing it one day to the next, it's definitely more score-able.\" \n\nThat means one winner already is decided. Carl Frampton has called on Leo Santa Cruz to complete the trilogy with a final showdown in Belfast after losing his WBA featherweight title in Las Vegas. Frampton was beaten for the first time in his career on a majority points decision at the MGM Grand as Santa Cruz regained the belt he lost to the Northern Irishman in July. Santa Cruz is open to the idea of a decider and Frampton wants the fight in his backyard.\n\n\"I hope so, I hope he is a man of his word and we can do it in Belfast,\" he said on Sky Sports 1. \"I have come to the States twice. We could do it four, five, six times. I hope we do it again. \"I am deeply disappointed but let's have a trilogy and have our names linked together forever and hopefully I can win 2-1.\"\n\nOne judge scored the contest at 114-114, but the other two gave it 115-113 in Santa Cruz's favour and the Mexican took a deserved victory. It was a smart performance by Santa Cruz, who improved immeasurably from the first bout in New York last summer, and his tactics shocked Frampton.\n\n\"I think it was the right decision, I thought it was close,\" the Northern Irishman added. \"He frustrated me at times, I didn't expect that game plan, the boxer got out-boxed by the brawler. I thought it was the right decision, I hope we can do it again, it was a close fight. \"I have got no excuses, I feel I want to say sorry, I feel like I have let everyone down. The best man won on the night. I am gutted. It was my fault.\"\n\nSanta Cruz admits he had to fight against his instinct as well as Frampton. \"I worked hard and did what I had t,\" he said. \"I fought a great fighter and let's make a third fight. He is a great fighter and a great counter-puncher. It was tough to change my style, in my head I wanted to go for it, but I was told to box him and that's what I did.\n\n\"I am a man of my word. Operating losses for the seventh consecutive year to near-break-even   \nEMBARGOED UNTIL SUNDAY, 1/29 AT NOON \n \nThe Detroit Regional Convention Facility Authority narrowed its operational loss for the seventh consecutive year in 2016 after paying down $13.5 million in taxable bonds, a move it says will save taxpayers about $11.7 million over the life of the bond issue or $7.75 million in present value dollars. \n \nThe early payment represented more than half of the  higher-interest $23.5 million taxable bond issue owed on the original $295.35 million in bonds taken out in November 2014, said Patrick Bero, CEO and COO of the authority, which has operational oversight for Detroit\u2019s Cobo Center. \n \nIt was made in addition to a scheduled principal payment of just over $7 million paid last October. \n \nNext year, the authority plans to pay off the remainder of the taxable bond issue and then dip into the tax-exempt debt owed, Bero said. \n \nThe early payment leaves the authority owing a total of just under $274.8 million, Bero said, due at various points between now and 2039. \n \nThe authority continued to operate at a loss last year but narrowed its deficit to $280,166 earnings before interest, depreciation and amortization, net of debt and operating subsidies. \n \nThe authority and Cobo management company SNG have narrowed the losses for seven consecutive years since taking on oversight of the convention center. \n \nIn 2015 it posted a $2.7 million loss and $3.4 million loss the year before. \n \nThe city was losing an estimated $21 million year on Cobo Center, the authority said, when it took over control in September 2009 under an agreement between the Michigan State Legislature, the City of Detroit, and Wayne, Oakland and Macomb counties. \n \nBero said the authority is approaching a break-even point operationally, nearly seven years before the 2023 deadline the state legislature set as the last year it will receive subsidies to help fund Cobo\u2019s operation.  He credits the recent renovation and subsequent increase in bookings with helping the events venue turn things around. \n \nThe authority completed a $279 million renovation and upgrade to Cobo Center on time and within budget in August 2015. Among other things, the upgrades created a 30,000-square-foot atrium with views of the Detroit River and Canada,  increased parking and improved traffic flow, upgraded infrastructure, enclosed loading docks and redeveloped the former Cobo Arena as a 40,000-square-foot grand ballroom. \n \nAdditionally, the authority said a $2 million technology upgrade was completed in mid-December to allow 32,000 simultaneous users on Cobo\u2019s Wi-Fi network. \n \nIn 2016, the event center hosted 16 city-wide conventions, including the annual North American International Auto Show. \n \nCobo lays claim to being the 17th largest convention center in the country with 723,000 square feet of exhibition space and nearly 1.5 million visitors each year.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Sherri Welch"},"topics":[{"name":"Transportation industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Detroit news","group":"US regional"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Detroit Regional Transportation Authority makes early, $13.5 million debt payment that will save taxpayers","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","countryCode":"US","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Crains Detroit Business","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169715140","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"217"},"name":"Crains Detroit Business","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","InformationTechnology"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.crainsdetroit.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695198969429","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:01:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:48:25Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

This year\u2019s Hollywood Red Carpet theme meant they got the star treatment. \n \n\u201cI thought it was the best because I got to wear my tux shirt,\u201d he said with a laugh, wearing a fake tuxedo shirt. \n \nAbout 250 fathers and daughters showed up for the Saturday afternoon dance that Thrutchley and his daughters attended. Greeley offers the dance at different times to help fathers with different schedules get a chance to bond with their daughters. Including the Friday evening and Saturday evening dance, almost 1,800 attended this weekend. From baby girls to adult women, daughters of all ages showed up with their fathers. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s great to see all the other dads getting together with their daughters and having a good time,\u201d Thrutchley said. \u201cWe\u2019re making memories here that\u2019ll last forever.\u201d \n \nThrutchley took his three daughters Shiloh, Coty and Hannah. Elvis impersonator George Gray showed up in his bright white Elvis costume, brightening the faces of both young and old. Thrutchley said the dance has grown into something special for his family. \n \n\u201cI just hope they keep doing it. One year we heard that they might stop doing it, and I was crushed,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is definitely a tradition for us.\u201d \n \nRecreation supervisor Andrea Haring said organizing the event isn\u2019t easy, but always worth it. \n \n\u201cOut of all my duties I have for the city \u2026 this is my most favorite,\u201d Haring said. \u201cIt\u2019s so worth it. Organisers claim this a record number of the little dogs in the one place at the one time. \n\nMark Ellis, the organiser of Sunday's Werriwa Wiener Dash at the Bungendore Show, believes the turnout of 154 dachshunds for the event constitutes a world record for the number of the sausage dogs in one place at one time.\n\n\"We had miniatures, long hairs, short hairs, standards and wire hairs,\" he said. \"They came from all over; some even travelled from Melbourne.\n\nWhile Mr Ellis wasn't able to engage the attention of the people from Guinness, who ruled the record being sought was too \"specialised\" to interest them, he is happy to claim the record with any other contenders needing to prove him wrong.\n\nAlthough the quirky event, which has captured the imagination of dachshund lovers from across NSW and the ACT, is only in its second year it has already become one of the feature events of the Bungendore Show.\n\nThis year's dash winner was Buddy, owned by Jacqueline Winzenberg of Page in the ACT. Buddy's award was presented by NSW Deputy Premier and local member John Barilaro.\n\nOne hundred and twenty seven dogs turned up for the inaugural event in 2016.\n\nBungendore Show, which was first held in the 1840s, has gone from strength to strength in recent decades, this year's showgirl, Hanna Darmody, 22, said.\n\nMs Darmody, whose family own a Bungendore butchery, said she could recall helping with the catering at the show as a toddler almost 20 years ago.\n\n\"I've seen the event grow as the town has grown,\" she said. \"It is a great bridge between country and city; the showgirl competition is a good way to get young people involved and promotes opportunities in agriculture.\"\n\nShow organisers said this year's event, which enjoyed the best weather conditions in three years, was an unqualified success with more than 2000 people passing through the gates before lunch.\n\nIn addition to the usual attractions in the show ring and the pavilions and the dachshund dash, the 2017 event offered visitors a chance to get a close look at the Anzac Centennial 18 pounder gun.\n\nThe World War I-era weapon, which also saw service during World War II,was restored by the Royal Australian Artillery Company in conjunction with veteran coach builder Jim Frecklington. NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"}],"wordCount":"481","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395958738&p=2kx&v=1&x=CVhdvWPbxrNXaOj2pqev3Q","id":"29395958738","content":"Labor warns that the NSW police commissioner must report to two ministers under the change \n\nThe appointment of a new minister for counter-terrorism in NSW has been slammed by the Labor opposition as irresponsible and against the public interest.\n\nUnveiling a cabinet reshuffle on Sunday, Premier Gladys Berejiklian announced corrections minister David Elliott \u2013 not police minister Troy Grant \u2013 would take on the new role.\n\nShe said it was required \"unfortunately due to the circumstances our world is in\".\n\n\"The sad reality is that this is an area of focus for governments around the world \u2013 NSW is already working closely with the Commonwealth and I want the Minister to take this work forward,\" Ms Berejiklian said.\n\n\"Mr Elliott will work closely with the Attorney General, Minister for Police, the Minister for Education, the Minister for Family and Community Services and the Minister for Multiculturalism, as well as our federal counterparts, to ensure a whole-of-government approach to this issue\".\n\nUnder the change, the Terrorism (Commonwealth Powers) Act and the Terrorism (Police Powers) Act will remain the responsibility of the Attorney General.\n\nMr Elliott will provide strategic policy direction for counter-terrorism in NSW, while the police will manage the tactical and operational response to terrorist attacks or threats.\n\nMr Elliott told Fairfax Media: \"Over the coming weeks I will be working to coordinate all stakeholders to ensure that the people of NSW can sleep soundly in the knowledge that we are as best prepared for any contingency as we can be.\"\n\nBut opposition leader Luke Foley said the appointment was the result of an irresponsible deal. He alleged that the Liberals wanted to wrest police from Mr Grant, a senior Nationals MP.\n\n\"The Nationals wanted police, the right wing faction of the Liberals wanted police,\" he said. \"So she split it in two.\"\n\n\"It's the police who keep us safe from terrorism,\" Mr Foley said.\n\n\"The police commissioner now has to report to two people. It's scandalous and another deal that is counter to the public interest.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the troubled relationship between the NSW attorney-general and minister for police has been addressed, with Ms Berejiklian confirming a reshaping of the much maligned \"justice cluster\".\n\nThe arrangement, whereby as justice and police minister Mr Grant held a more senior position than then attorney-general Gabrielle Upton, was heavily criticised by the legal profession.\n\nThe NSW Bar Association said it provided Mr Grant \"with unprecedented power in determining legal policy without the historical checks and balances\".\n\nThe NSW Law Society warned the arrangement meant police were \"ostensibly responsible for criminal law policy, while at the same time, the traditional roles of the attorney-general as first law officer of the state, which includes preserving civil liberties, are being eroded\".\n\nMs Berejiklian has confirmed the cluster has been reworked so that new attorney-general Mark Speakman, SC, is the lead minister.
